text:
*This should not be possible*, Gunnery Sergeant Karim Poole thought, staring at the little stowaway. 
The girl stared back at him, lower lip trembling, a curl of dark hair stuck to a teary cheek. “Have you seen my mommy?” She backed into the corner between the glossy white rib of the corridor and the matte wall, looking as if she might flee if he gave the wrong answer.
*Ah, fuck, why me? I’m absolute dogshit with kids*. “We’ll find her,” he told her, wincing at how awkward and unconvincing it came out. *What on Blessed Earth are you doing here, anyway?*
How did a little girl somehow get onto a warship in deep cover in contested space? Even if she’d somehow made it into the docking facility on a base, they’d been out here for months. Who had she survived all this time without being discovered? 
What had she been *eating*? 
It was a silly question to be obsessed with, but it was the one he couldn’t get out of his head. 
“What’s your name, sweetie?” he asked. It didn’t sound any more natural than the last time he’d spoken. 
“Kel,” she quavered.
*Oh, shit,* please *don’t start crying again, kid*. “That’s a great name,” he said quickly. “My best friend’s name is Kel.” It wasn’t a common name. At least this gave him something to talk about. “You know what, let’s go find her and she can help us find your mom.”
She sniffled.
Kel, his best friend and occasional lover, seemed like she’d be good with kids. It wasn’t really something you could really know about your crewmates, seeing as this sort of years-long mission didn’t really give you a chance to watch anyone interact with minors, but she seemed like she’d be good with kids. At least, she was certain to be better than him. 
The little girl considered him, chewing a nail. 
“Come on, just follow me,” he urged her, and turned toward the crew quarters. Neither of them were on duty, and his wristlet showed Kel in the lounge when he queried it. 
He turned back when she didn’t respond, to make sure she was following, and froze.
The p-way was empty.
“What the—?” he grumbled out loud, stopping himself before voicing the profanity. There wasn’t anywhere she could go that he wouldn’t be able to see her. The passageway curved very slightly, but he didn’t think a kid that small could run fast enough to get out of his sightline. He’d only been facing away from her for a few seconds. All of the rooms required a scan to open the doors, and her biometrics wouldn’t be in the system. There was nowhere she could have gone.
The ever-present hum of the p-way seemed very loud.
The ribs weren’t wide enough for her to fully hide behind, but he strode back along the corridor anyway, checking behind each one. 
As he approached a crossway, he heard crying. *How did you get all the way over here so fast, kiddo?*
He turned into the crossway and froze. 
It wasn’t the little girl. 
It was Kel. 
“Kel?” he whispered. 
She didn’t look up. She had her arms folded against the bulkhead, face buried in them, sobbing. Her tight cap of dark curls looked waterlogged, as if she’d just gotten out of the shower.
He cleared his throat. “Kel?”
She didn’t seem to hear him. 
He took a tentative step toward her. Kel was not the sort of person who sobbed in passageways. Something must be really wrong. 
She finally looked up at him, or that’s what he thought at first. Her face was livid, eyes reddened. “Don’t you dare walk away from me,” she snarled.
“I’m… not,” he blurted. “Kel, are you okay? I’m not walking away from you. I’m right here.”
She bared her teeth. “If you leave, now, don’t think you’re coming back.”
“What are you talking about?” Clearly, something was very wrong with her. “Kel, take a breath and talk to me.”
“I mean it.” 
A tingle of unease worked its way up his spine. He was no longer sure she was looking at him, or that she was even seeing him. She seemed to be looking past him.
He turned. 
The passageway behind him was empty. 
“What’s going—?” he started to ask as he turned back to her. 
The passageway in front of him was also empty.
*What the absolute fucking FUCK.*
The hum of the p-way seemed very loud.
The storage deck was always quiet. He’d come down here to get some board games out of his unit, but on second thought, he didn’t really need them. *I can come back for them another time. Right now, I just want to be where there are a lot of other people*.
He turned back to head to the lift. And maybe to Medical. 
And then he heard it behind him. 
*Don’t do it. Your mind’s playing some kind of trick on you. There’s no way there could be a little girl on this ship, and if that was Kel, the best thing you can do for her is get her some formal help*. 
The crying grew louder. 
*Fuck.* He stopped walking. *No. Ignore it. Straight to Medical.* Almost despite himself, he turned around. 
An elderly woman lay on the deck, struggling feebly. 
*She might not even be real.* 
“Hello?” he called. “Ma’am, do you need medical assistance?”
“Help me,” she wheezed. “Someone help me.”
As if something else was dragging him toward her, he took a step forward. “I’ll get you some help, ma’am. What’s your name?”
She groaned, putting a hand to her side. “My name is Kel Danvers. Please, can anyone hear me? I need help.”
It felt like his skin was frozen and cracking. *This isn’t possible.*
“Please,” she pled.
*Nope. Absolutely not. Fuck all this.* He turned and ran all the way to the lift. He couldn’t run inside the lift, so he paced back and forth until the door opened, then ran toward Medical. 
He’d almost made it there when he collided bodily with Private First-Class Andre Ortega. 
“Christ,” Ortega swore, then turned red. “I’m sorry, sir.”
“My fault,” Karim choked out. 
“Did you hear? About the thing they found? That’s why we changed course. We’re orbiting it.”
*Just get out of my way, kid. I need my head examined.* “What thing?” he asked wearily.
“The… I don’t know what to call it, sir. I was on the bridge taking lunch orders when they spotted it, so I saw it. On the screen, I mean. We weren’t close enough yet to see it out the portholes.” 
“Spit it out, Private,” Karim snapped. “What kind of thing are you talking about it?”
“It’s like a… It looks sort of gold-colored. It’s like a… honeycomb? It’s geometric. And huge. Much bigger than the ship.”
“I hadn’t heard about it,” he mumbled. “Look, Ortega, I’m not feeling well. I’m on my way to Medical. I’ll be eager to hear all about it after I get checked out.”
“Of course, sir. I hope you feel better soon.” Ortega stepped aside, smiling nervously, his big front teeth flashing. 
Karim managed to fend off several other conversations on his way into Medical.
“What can I do for you, Poole?” the doctor asked. He was younger than Karim generally liked his doctors to be, but he had the gruff lack of bedside manner Karim associated with medical competence, so he felt reality settling back into its normal patterns.
“I think I’m seeing things, Doc. I was down in storage and I— I saw people who couldn’t be there.”
“You’re off-duty,” the doctor observed. “Have you been drinking?”
Karim shook his head. 
The doctor eyed him, his long dark eyes narrowing. “Don’t panic, Poole. The combination of space and stress does strange things to the human mind, especially when you’re out here for more than a few months. You wouldn’t be the first person on this ship to see things that aren’t there. It doesn’t mean there’s anything wrong with you that sleep aids and some R&R won’t fix. We’ll do a full scan, make sure there’s nothing more than that going on, but that’s probably all it is.”
“Thanks, Doc.” He let out a long breath. “It’s just that—” 
“Stay off the storage deck for a while.” The doctor grinned at him. “It’s eerie down there even when we’re not in deep space. Stay up here where it’s brightly lit and busy until you’re feeling back to normal. Doctor’s orders.”
“Aye-aye, sir.” 
“Good. Let’s get you that scan.” The doctor turned back to the desk in the exam room, hitting the nurse call-button. “We’ll just—”
A red light above the door began flashing, and what sounded like an alarm rang shrilly.
There was a soft knock at the door.
“Come in,” the doctor called.
The door opened partially and a nurse stuck his head into the space. “Doc, we’ve got a medical emergency. Someone was out doing external maintenance and got her leg caught in a hinge. It seems like it’s mangled pretty bad, and her comms cut out, so she was out there for a while. Her suit didn’t rupture, but she passed out.”
The doctor pushed himself to his feet. “You’ve told them to prep the surgery pod?”
“Yes.”
“Okay, I’ll head to the prep room.”
“Poole, I’ll put in an order relieving you from duty for the next couple weeks. Can you come back tomorrow for a scan?”
“Sure, Doc.” He hesitated, then turned to the nurse, compelled by an odd chill that felt almost like a premonition. “I’m sorry, but could you tell me who was injured?”
The nurse looked at the doctor, who shrugged permission. “It was Staff Sergeant Kel Danvers.”

Look at this stupid girl, out in the middle of the night in a blizzard, her horse floundering through chest-high snowdrifts, in the dark and the freezing cold, riding like her life depends on it. Two girls, actually, because her maid Cecelia is too brave and too loyal for her own good. 
I guess she’s not really a girl. She’s a full-grown woman, dashing impetuously through the storm, but we’re always youngest in our most desperate moments. 
That’s me, or rather it was me, a long time ago. On my way to try to save the man I love. 
On Christmas, of all nights. 
Actually, forget all that “poor girl” stuff. Let’s spare a minute to consider that poor horse. His name was Jonquil, and he didn’t deserve to be caught up in any of this. He certainly hadn’t married a man who got him into disaster after disaster, and he certainly didn’t decide he couldn’t accept being a widow and that he needed to take extreme measures to avoid it. He could have bucked me off into the snow and headed for the nearest village where some peasant would have been delighted to receive him as a mysterious Christmas gift. But he didn’t. He just fought his way through that snow, probably whinnying *Winnie, what have you gotten us into?* under his breath.
Oh, come on, how dangerous could it be, I bet you’re asking, riding a horse in the snow? You should probably consider, before you get too skeptical that I was in any real peril, that back in the day you could die from a paper cut. Everything was trying to kill us. These days people hear about our average lifespans and like to think that in my era, you were ancient at 30. That wasn’t true. It’s not how averages work. You were still a fairly young adult at 30, and we had our share of people in their 70s and 80s and even a handful who made it to their 90s. We didn’t age faster. Most of us just died young. If plague or wounds or brigands didn’t get us, politics was always waiting on the scaffold with a bloody axe in its hands. 
Don’t worry, the girl’s going to make it to London safely, despite the foolhardiness of undertaking a month-long, 350-mile ride in the brutal Scottish winter. At least this fool was hardy, although it did take quite a toll on her health. She’ll make it all the way to the court of George I, the Protestant pretender, where she’ll plead with him not to kill her husband, and he’ll ignore her. She won’t give up, on the tiles of his courtroom, as she clings to his robe and he drags her across the room, any more than she gave up in the snow and the dark and the biting wind. 
“Never trust a Scot,” Catherine Walpole sneered at me while her monarch tried to slink away with me still attached as firmly as a burr to his sleeve. “She’s probably got a dagger up her sleeve.”
Up your sleeve is where you hide tricks, not dirks, you silly English bint. Not that you’d know, since there’s not a thought in your outrageously bewigged head besides extravagant clothes and jewels and who you’re going to have your next affair with. What have you ever known about desperation? My knife was at my belt, of course, but there was no chance of using it successfully. I was already thinking, since this wasn’t going well, about other things you could hide in clothing. *Vestis virum facit*, after all. 
Maybe she was right to pay so much attention to her dresses. Used correctly, a good dress can achieve things an army could never.
Was he worth all this effort, you’re probably wondering, before you’ve even heard the half of it? 
I’ve been called calculating, but the valuations of love are beyond my skill. I have no idea. He was the source of almost all of my misery and I wouldn’t change a minute of it. 
We were young when I met. Not for the time—I was 19, which wasn’t young at all to be married, but I don’t know if that means I had good judgment. 
If you’re wondering what it was that convinced me, well, a good Catholic girl doesn’t kiss and tell, but let me tell you: that kiss.
We were at the French court, and I was a charmer, so I had plenty to compare it to, but I’ll leave all those liaisons dangereuses to the imagination. I was discreet, of course, being neither dummy nor dud. 
We kissed, I fell under his spell, and the rest—the parts that don’t matter nearly as much—is in the history books. Reader, I married him.
His name was William. William and Winifred. Willy and Winnie—isn’t that adorable? Or Will and Win, which makes us sound like quite the power couple. Never mind that it was his weakness of will that kept getting us in trouble, forcing me to find wins where I could manufacture them. And yet any time I tried to be firm with him, he’d look at me with his sweet eyes and I’d remember the boy I’d kissed in the French court and my better sense would take wing. 
Depending on your perspective, I was either doomed by my family history to the sort of trouble he got me in, or I’d seen enough of it that I should have known better. 
My father got caught up in the anti-Catholic hysteria of his day and spent six awful years suffering in the Tower of London since they believed he’d been involved in a Catholic plot to overthrow the British throne. According to gossips, my mother contrived a disastrously ill-conceived plot to free him, and got herself arrested for the trouble, although they were both freed eventually. 
In truth, the only thing my mother did wrong was have too kind a heart. She gave money to Catholic prisoners, and the midwife who carried it to them for her got involved with a man named Thomas Dangerfield. Dangerfield lost his head (metaphorically) over my mother’s almoner, and didn’t take it well when she wasn’t symmetrically smitten, which led him to fabricate a Catholic plot against the English throne just to implicate her, in which my mother almost lost her head (literally) before the whole thing got straightened out.
Never trust a man with “danger” in his name, says I. 
Children should strive to succeed where their parents have failed, so instead of being an innocent freed from the Tower after being falsely accused of participation in a fake Catholic plot against the King of England, Willie and I participated in a real Catholic uprising against the king of England, trying to put a Scottish Catholic king in his place. Not to brag, but we got away Scot-free. 
It wasn’t just my parents, either, who were failing at being sensible role models.
The year after I got married, my older brother was languishing in Ghent because he was literally too gaunt and ill to leave, after being implicated in a Catholic plot to overthrow the British throne. You might recognize the name Ghent—it’s where John of Gaunt was from, one of the men that ultimately got us in all this king-switching trouble. From my lofty current perspective of being dead and all, I can tell you that in retrospect it probably would have been better for our sceptred isle to just wait out the snowballing disaster that was Richard II than to replace him, given the avalanche of problems that little well-intentioned endeavor ended up causing. But of course, hindsight is e’er eagle-eyed. 
Speaking of snowballs…
Let’s return to that girl on her horse, in the seemingly endless darkness and cold and whirling snow, on Christmas Eve. 
We’ll get through all the history that got her there, and everything that came after, but she was still close enough to home that she could have turned back and let Providence handle events for itself. That was the moment, her heart quailing as the cold and hunger really sank in and poor faithful Jonquil stumbled in the snow like he might not make it to lodgings before winter took them all, that she decided what was most important to her. 
I’m sorry. I just realized I haven’t introduced her. Me. Being dead does tend to attenuate both your sense of time and your manners. 
My name is Lady Winifred Maxwell, née Herbert, Countess of Nithsdale.
I’m most famous for breaking my husband, William Maxwell, 5th Earl of Nithsdale, out of the Tower of London, but there’s a lot more to me than that.

text:
It is a sunny Thursday morning in April. Detective Benjamin Singer is attending a lecture for the first time in decades, and daydreaming about murder. 
The environment is, to be fair, superbly suited to sending a mind off into the fields of imagination, to gather rosebuds or wool or—in Singer’s case—darker mental artifacts. The building itself is a fantastic faux-medieval edifice with a mournful ecclesiastical air, its architecture doubtlessly intended to evoke lofty ideals of its lecture halls as “cathedrals of learning,” back a few centuries ago when people were willing to pay to build that sort of thing. The cloudy gothic-arched windows have a pleasant draping of wisteria vines which hover along the edges, the distortion of the aged and distorted glass giving them the appearance of flouncy green-and-purple valences. Inside, ancient radiators wheeze in a way that suggests the mechanical version of atherosclerosis, producing a soothing white-noise hiss. The air is laden with the olfactory equivalent of a sleepy academic hush: that strange and elusive scent that old buildings breathe forth when the sun heats their dust. The busy fingers of the students, trying to capture Professor Green’s teachings, tap their laptop keys in a rhythmic susurrus. 
All in all, it’s a perfectly crafted environment for a daydream, a meditation, or even a nap—not because it’s boring, but simply because it’s serene. 
“In the premodern world,” Green is saying, “justice was not about rehabilitation. That’s a very modern idea, very influenced by western ideas of individualism. We see the criminal as an individual who needs either punishment to pay a debt to society or rehabilitation to be safe to rejoin it. In the ancient world, however, the criminal represented not an individual who did wrong, but problem with the community. A sort of tear or wound in it, that had to be healed or cleansed. Which approach sounds better to you?”
He pauses, although it doesn’t seem like he has much expectation of a response from the diligent tappers. It’s more of a rhythmic choice.
“It might seem like that sense of collective responsibility is kinder, as if they’re not really blaming the criminal. And in some senses that’s true. At the same time, they don’t really care about what happens to him. They might kill him or exile him, and it doesn’t matter if he stole something because his family was starving, or killed someone who’d harmed him. They weren’t concerned with his reasons for doing it—they just needed to get rid of the stain, in one way or another.”
Singer is only half-listening, since he’s also out wandering the fertile imaginatory fields of present-day crime-solving. But he’s present enough to be surprised at how much he’s enjoying sitting here in a lecture hall, listening to a classics professor give a lecture. He wonders, idly, if he might have wasted his time in college. 
He’d fully inhabited his callow days—no one had ever accused college-age Benny of being “wise beyond his years” or “an old soul” or any other such pablum—and his time at university was a hazy stretch of football games and beer and awkward dates and dehydration headaches. He’d gone because it was what kids from good middle-class families did after high school, and because his parents took seriously the commandment that “all your children shall be learned.” They couldn’t ensure that he’d actually absorb any learning, but they performed their responsibility to expose him to it admirably. 
However, Singer had grown into that rarest of specimens, especially in the machismo-scorched ranks of the police force: a man who had transformed, in the midst of an often brutish environment, into a sensitive, bookish soul. Now in what his British mother had always called a person’s “middage,” he flatters himself that he’s taken on a professorial air among his colleagues, though he’s never had the courage to probe whether they’d agree with that characterization. It makes him feel a sort of warm, self-congratulatory collegiality with Professor Green, a pleasant anticipation that when this lecture ends and he approaches the other gentlemen, they’ll engage in a mutually admiring, elevated discourse of the sort he can’t have with his actual coworkers.
Singer actually is here to work, not just to enjoy a brief opportunity to experience what it might have been like not to waste his obligatory stint in academia. 
Professor Green has been recommended to him as an expert who might help him solve an intriguing puzzle posed by evidence from his current case: a mutilated antique volume in Greek, found beside the body of the victim of a presumed homicide.
The victim was an antiquarian of some means—his modest fortune seems almost quaint in these days of tech tycoons and biopharma billionaires, but it’s still life-changing lucre for the average Joe. The deceased might have said, without irony, that he was comfortable, since these days one has to be wealthy to be comfortable. 
It’s déclassé, certainly, to delight in a murder. The antiquarian was a human being who had his life prematurely taken from him and, yes yes, deserved to live out the two or three years he had left at the age of 97 in peace, rather than dying violently. Violently, at least, in the sense that murder is inherently violent, since death was caused by a cocktail of sleeping pills and narcotic painkillers. Dying via the fun drugs at the wealthy (both materially and in years) age of 97 seems to Singer a rather ideal way to go, but he recognizes that he must pay homage to the idea that this is first a great tragedy and only secondly a delicious puzzle. 
“Crime, to us, indicates not just a type of act but a type of person,” Green is saying. He sneezes a little, for no apparent reason, since the dust motes sparkling plentifully in the shaft of sunlight laying a gentle hand upon his silver hair have remained consistent in quantity. “We define criminals as a separate category of people. We’ve inherited this from what we call biological positivism, which wasn’t called that in the Victorian era but certainly got its pop culture start there. They believed criminals were biologically different from normal people. You can see this assumption in play in the practice of phrenology, where they’d measure the dimensions of someone’s skull and the distance between their eyes to try to determine if they had criminal tendencies. The salt air, thick with the scent of brine and seaweed, whipped Amelia’s hair across her face as she wrestled with her oversized beach umbrella. Kennebunkport, Maine, in all its postcard-perfect glory, was living up to its reputation for blustery breezes. She finally managed to jam the umbrella’s spike into the sand, securing it just as a particularly strong gust threatened to send it tumbling down the beach.
Amelia sighed, brushing a stray strand of blonde hair from her eyes. This was supposed to be a relaxing vacation, a week of sun, sand, and solitude after a particularly brutal year in the New York advertising world. So far, the solitude was winning. She’d arrived at her charming, albeit slightly creaky, rented cottage the previous afternoon, unpacked, and promptly fallen asleep. This morning, determined to embrace the coastal Maine experience, she’d ventured out to Goose Rocks Beach, armed with a stack of paperbacks and a resolve to unwind.
She settled into her beach chair, adjusting her sunglasses and pulling her straw hat lower over her face. The rhythmic crash of the waves against the shore was soothing, and she finally began to feel the tension easing from her shoulders. She opened her book, a lighthearted romance about a baker who falls in love with a rugged firefighter, and lost herself in the story.
A sudden shadow fell across her page. Amelia looked up, shielding her eyes from the sun. Standing before her was a man, tall and broad-shouldered, with sun-kissed skin and eyes the color of the deep ocean. He wore faded jeans, a worn navy blue sweatshirt, and rubber boots that looked like they’d seen their fair share of ocean spray. He held a large, rectangular wooden trap in his hands. A lobsterman.
“Excuse me,” he said, his voice a low rumble that was almost drowned out by the crashing waves. “I need to check my traps. I try to stay out of the way of the beachgoers, but this one’s pretty close to shore.”
Amelia blinked, momentarily speechless. He was… breathtaking. Ruggedly handsome, with a weathered face that spoke of a life spent outdoors. She could practically smell the sea on him.
“Oh, of course,” she stammered, scrambling to her feet. “I didn’t even see them.”
He smiled, a flash of white teeth against his tanned skin. “They blend in pretty well with the rocks. Name’s Ben.”
“Amelia,” she replied, shaking his outstretched hand. His grip was firm and calloused, sending a surprising jolt of electricity through her.
Ben turned his attention to the trap, carefully placing it on the sand. He knelt down, his movements fluid and practiced, and began to inspect it. Amelia watched him, fascinated. He worked with a quiet concentration, his brow furrowed in concentration.
“So,” Amelia said, trying to break the slightly awkward silence. “You’re a lobsterman?”
Ben glanced up, a grin playing on his lips. “Guilty as charged. Been doing it since I was old enough to bait a trap.”
“It must be… interesting,” Amelia said, searching for the right word. “A challenging way to make a living.”
“It has its moments,” Ben admitted. “Long hours, tough weather. But there’s nothing like being out on the water, watching the sun rise. And the lobsters aren’t bad either.” He winked.
He finished checking the trap and stood up, wiping his hands on his jeans. “Well, I should get going. Don’t want to keep my boat waiting.” He gestured out towards the ocean, where a small lobster boat bobbed gently in the waves.
“It was nice meeting you, Amelia,” he said, his eyes meeting hers.
“You too, Ben,” she replied, feeling a blush creeping up her neck.
He turned and walked towards the water’s edge, his boots sinking slightly into the wet sand. He waded out to the boat, climbed aboard with an easy grace, and started the engine. With a roar, the boat pulled away from the shore, heading out into the open ocean.
Amelia watched him go, her heart beating a little faster than usual. She couldn’t explain it, but there was something about Ben that had captivated her. Maybe it was his rugged charm, his connection to the sea, or simply the fact that he was the first person she’d actually spoken to since arriving in Kennebunkport. Whatever it was, she couldn’t shake the feeling that their paths were destined to cross again.
She returned to her beach chair, but her book no longer held her interest. She kept glancing out at the ocean, searching for Ben’s boat. The image of his sun-kissed face and ocean-blue eyes was burned into her mind.
The rest of the afternoon passed in a blur. Amelia tried to relax, but her thoughts kept drifting back to Ben. She imagined him out on the water, hauling in traps, battling the waves. She wondered about his life, his family, what he did when he wasn’t fishing for lobsters.
As the sun began to dip below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of orange and pink, Amelia decided to head back to her cottage. She packed up her things, feeling a sense of anticipation for what the next day might bring.
Back at the cottage, Amelia took a long, hot shower, washing away the sand and salt from her skin. She changed into a pair of comfortable jeans and a light sweater, and decided to walk into town for dinner.
The town of Kennebunkport was bustling with activity. Tourists strolled along the streets, browsing the shops and admiring the charming architecture. The air was filled with the sounds of laughter, conversation, and the distant cry of seagulls.
Amelia found a small, cozy restaurant overlooking the harbor and ordered a bowl of clam chowder and a glass of white wine. As she ate, she couldn’t help but scan the faces of the other diners, half expecting to see Ben.
He wasn’t there.
Disappointment pricked at her, but she quickly brushed it aside. It was silly to think she’d see him again so soon. Kennebunkport was a small town, but not that small.
After dinner, Amelia strolled along the harbor, enjoying the cool evening air. The lights from the boats and the surrounding buildings reflected on the water, creating a magical scene. She stopped to watch a group of fishermen unloading their catch, the smell of fresh fish mingling with the salty air.
As she turned to leave, she saw him.
Ben.
He was standing near the edge of the dock, talking to another man. He was wearing a different sweatshirt, a dark green one, but Amelia recognized him instantly. Her heart skipped a beat.
She hesitated, unsure whether to approach him. What would she say? Would he even remember her?
Before she could decide, Ben turned and saw her. His eyes widened slightly, and a smile spread across his face.
“Amelia!” he called out, waving to her.
She couldn’t help but smile back. The feeling of anticipation that had been building inside her all day suddenly burst forth. This was it. Their paths were crossing again. And this time, she had a feeling it was more than just a chance encounter.

Sarah Chen stared at Congressman James Barrett's reflection in her laptop screen, and for a fraction of a second, his face wasn't his face at all.
She blinked, and the moment passed. Barrett continued pacing behind her desk, rehearsing his speech for tomorrow's House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing. His cadence was perfect as always—measured yet passionate, with just the right touch of gravitas. Every pause calculated for maximum impact.
“The American people deserve to know,” he declared, “exactly how their tax dollars are being spent overseas. And more importantly, they deserve to know *why*.”
Sarah's fingers flew across the keyboard, making minor adjustments to the speech text. After sixteen months as Barrett's senior legislative aide, she could anticipate his tweaks before he made them. A strengthened verb here, a shortened sentence there. Polish the rhetoric until it gleamed.
But she couldn't shake what she'd seen in that reflection. Or thought she'd seen. For just an instant, Barrett's familiar features—the strong jaw, the distinguished salt-and-pepper hair that drove his Twitter followers wild, the penetrating blue eyes—had seemed to... shift. Like a mask slipping, revealing something underneath. Something wrong.
*Sleep deprivation*, she told herself. She'd been pulling fourteen-hour days all week, preparing for this hearing. The coffee maker in the office kitchen had become her closest friend, and her studio apartment in Columbia Heights was starting to feel like an expensive storage unit for her clothes.
“Sarah?” Barrett's voice pulled her back to the present. He'd stopped pacing and was looking at her expectantly. “What do you think about adding a personal anecdote there? Something about my time in the Peace Corps?”
“I...” Sarah hesitated. The Peace Corps story was a good one—Barrett had spent two years building schools in Nicaragua before law school. It played well with both progressives and moderates, humanizing him while emphasizing his commitment to smart, sustainable foreign aid. They'd used it dozens of times.
But for the first time, she found herself wondering: had anyone ever actually verified that story?
“Sarah?” Barrett prompted again. The overhead fluorescents caught his eyes at an odd angle, and for a moment they looked almost glassy, like marbles. Or camera lenses.
She suppressed a shiver. “Sorry, sir. Yes, I think the Peace Corps angle works well there. I can pull from your Guatemala speech last month—the part about Maria and her daughter?”
“Perfect.” Barrett flashed his trademark smile, the one that had launched a thousand campaign ads. “What would I do without you?”
*Get a new handler*, whispered a treacherous voice in the back of her mind.
Sarah forced herself to smile back and pulled up the Guatemala speech file. As she copied the relevant section, a calendar notification popped up on her screen: “Congressman Barrett - Quarterly Performance Review - 9:00 PM.”
She frowned. “Sir? I don't have any performance review scheduled for—”
The words died in her throat as she turned around. Barrett was gone. The office door was closed, though she hadn't heard it open or shut. And taped to the inside of the door was a plain white envelope with her name typed on it.
Sarah glanced at her phone: 8:57 PM. The rest of the staff had left hours ago. In the sudden silence, she could hear the hum of the fluorescent lights, the soft whir of her laptop fan, and her own heartbeat, growing faster by the second.
*This is crazy*, she thought. *I'm being paranoid. There's probably a perfectly reasonable explanation for...*
But she was already moving toward the door, her hand trembling slightly as she reached for the envelope. Inside was a single sheet of paper. The message was brief, typed in a plain font:
“Dear Ms. Chen,
Your suspicions are correct. The man you know as James Barrett is not what he appears to be. If you want to know the truth, come to the Lincoln Memorial at midnight. Come alone. Delete this message after reading.
For your own safety, tell no one what you've seen. They're watching.
A Friend”
Sarah read the message three times, her mind racing. This had to be a prank, right? Maybe Chelsea from Communications trying to freak her out, or that smug new intern who thought he was funny. But...
She thought about Barrett's reflection in her screen. The way his face had seemed to glitch, just for an instant. The oddly mechanical precision of his movements lately. The fact that she'd never once, in sixteen months, seen him eat or drink anything.
A new notification popped up on her laptop: “Meeting Location Changed - Cannon House Building Sub-basement Level B - 9:15 PM.”
She'd worked in this building for nearly two years and had never heard of a Level B.
Sarah looked at the envelope in her shaking hands, then at her laptop screen, then at Barrett's empty office. Through the window, she could see the Capitol dome illuminated against the dark sky, majestic and immutable. The heart of American democracy.
*What the hell am I involved in?*
She had two choices. She could delete the message, go home, and pretend this night never happened. Keep writing speeches, scheduling meetings, helping a man she'd admired become the next President of the United States. Keep her head down. Stay safe.
Or she could start pulling on this thread and see what unraveled.
Sarah Chen took a deep breath, dropped the envelope into her paper shredder, and opened her laptop's calendar app. Her fingers moved swiftly across the keyboard as she created a new event for midnight at the Lincoln Memorial.
The fluorescent lights flickered once, and in the brief moment of darkness, she could have sworn she saw a red dot appear on her office wall—like the recording light on a camera.
Or a targeting laser.
She grabbed her coat and phone, leaving her laptop behind. As she hurried toward the elevator, she tried not to think about the fact that she'd never seen Barrett leave his office.
Or about the sound now coming from behind his closed door, which might have been footsteps.
Or might have been servos whirring to life.

The wind howled over the barren expanse, tugging at the edges of Dr. Elias Vinter’s coat as he crouched in the muddy trench. Above him, the pale Northern sun struggled to pierce through the dense, slate-colored clouds, casting a muted light over the archaeological site. It was the third week of the dig, and morale among the team was waning. The promise of a long-forgotten settlement buried beneath the peatlands had yielded little more than fragments of pottery and weathered tools. Most of the students had retreated to the warmth of the base camp, leaving Elias alone to sift through the cold, unyielding earth.
He’d almost missed it. The edge of his trowel had scraped against something hard, something that didn’t match the brittle texture of bone or the coarse grain of stone tools. His heart quickened as he dug more carefully, brushing away the damp soil with trembling hands. Inch by inch, the object revealed itself: a small figurine, no more than six inches tall, carved from a dark, unidentifiable material that seemed to drink in the light rather than reflect it.
Elias held his breath as he lifted it free from its resting place. The figure was humanoid but distorted, its limbs elongated and bent at unnatural angles. The face was a grotesque mask of sharp angles and deep hollows, the mouth locked in a grimace that seemed to shift subtly when viewed from different angles. Runes—archaic and unfamiliar—were etched into its surface, spiraling in patterns that hurt his eyes if he stared too long.
The air around him felt suddenly heavier, pressing down on his shoulders like an invisible weight. A shiver ran through him, though the wind had stilled. He glanced over his shoulder, half-expecting to see someone standing at the edge of the trench, but he was alone. The site was silent save for the distant caw of a raven.
Elias knew he should call over one of his colleagues, document the discovery properly. But something held him back. A voice in the back of his mind—quiet yet insistent—urged him to keep it for himself. Just for now. Just until he could figure out what it was.
Slipping the figurine into the deep pocket of his coat, he smoothed the earth over the hole and stood, brushing the dirt from his gloves. He felt the weight of the object against his side as he made his way back to the camp, a comforting yet disconcerting presence. The runes, the twisted form—they gnawed at the edges of his thoughts, stirring questions he couldn’t yet articulate.
#
---
#
That night, in the dim solitude of his tent, Elias laid the figurine on his makeshift desk, a battered wooden crate piled with notes and sketches. He lit a lantern, its warm glow casting flickering shadows that seemed to dance and writhe across the canvas walls. The figurine seemed to absorb the light, its surface remaining stubbornly matte, as though rejecting the very notion of illumination.
He examined it more closely, running his fingers over the runes. The carvings were impossibly fine, far more intricate than anything he’d seen in the region’s typical artifacts. Yet there was a crudeness to the figure itself, a rawness that suggested it had been shaped by an unsteady hand—or perhaps one guided by something other than skill.
Elias reached for his notebook, intending to sketch the figurine and jot down his observations, but as he stared at it, the words refused to come. His pencil hovered over the page, the blank expanse mocking him. The lines of the figurine blurred, twisted, as if the object were shifting under his gaze. He blinked hard and shook his head, breaking the spell.
He tried to tell himself it was nothing—fatigue, the dim light, the isolation of the dig site playing tricks on his mind. But when he looked back at the figurine, he couldn’t shake the feeling that it was watching him.
#
---
#
In the days that followed, Elias found himself drawn to the figurine with a compulsion that bordered on obsession. He kept it hidden, wrapped in a cloth and tucked away in his satchel during the day, always within reach. At night, he’d sit for hours in his tent, studying its every detail. The runes seemed to shift when he wasn’t looking, their patterns rearranging themselves into forms that defied logical interpretation. He began to dream of them, jagged symbols etched into his mind, pulsing with an otherworldly glow.
The dreams grew more vivid with each passing night. He saw himself wandering through an endless, fog-shrouded forest, the ground beneath his feet slick with black mud. The trees loomed tall and skeletal, their branches reaching like gnarled fingers toward a sky that churned with roiling shadows. In the distance, he could hear whispers—a language he didn’t understand but somehow knew was meant for him.
When he woke, he felt drained, as though he’d spent the night clawing his way through that endless mire. His colleagues began to notice the change in him. His once meticulous notes grew sparse and disorganized. His responses to their questions were clipped, his temper fraying at the edges. The site’s lead archaeologist, Dr. Margit Lindholm, pulled him aside one afternoon, her brow furrowed with concern.
“Elias, are you all right? You’ve been… distant. Distracted. If something’s wrong, you can talk to me.”
He forced a smile that didn’t reach his eyes. “I’m fine. Just tired. This dig… it’s taking longer than I expected.”
Margit didn’t look convinced, but she let it drop. “Well, take care of yourself. We’re all tired, but you look like you’ve been carrying the weight of the world.”
Elias nodded, his hand instinctively brushing against the pocket where the figurine rested. “I’ll be fine. Just need some rest.”
But rest was the last thing he found. That night, the dreams took a darker turn. The whispers grew louder, more insistent, filling his mind with fragments of meaning he couldn’t piece together. He saw the figurine in his dream, its runes glowing with a malevolent light, and felt an overwhelming urge to kneel before it. When he woke, he was on the floor of his tent, dirt smeared across his face and hands as though he’d been clawing at the ground in his sleep.
#
---
#
By the end of the week, the change in Elias was undeniable. His skin was pale and drawn, his eyes sunken and shadowed. He began avoiding his colleagues altogether, retreating to the trench where he’d found the figurine and spending hours digging aimlessly, as though searching for something he couldn’t name. The others whispered about him, their concern tinged with unease.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the camp was bathed in the cool blue of twilight, Elias made a decision. He would leave the site. The figurine had become a burden he could no longer share, a secret too heavy to bear. But as he packed his belongings, he hesitated, the weight of the object in his hands anchoring him in place.
The runes glowed faintly in the dim light, pulsing like a heartbeat. He felt a strange clarity wash over him, a certainty that the figurine wasn’t just an artifact. It was a key—to what, he didn’t know. But it called to him, and he couldn’t ignore its pull.
Elias sat down on the edge of his cot, the figurine cradled in his hands. The air in the tent grew thick, the shadows deepening until they seemed to press against him. A faint hum filled the space, resonating in his chest, and he felt the world tilt beneath him. The whispers returned, clearer now, their words just on the edge of comprehension.
And then, for the first time, the figurine moved.
It was subtle—a shift, a slight bending of its twisted limbs. But it was enough to send a jolt of terror through Elias. He dropped it, stumbling back as it landed upright on the floor, its grotesque face turned toward him. The hum grew louder, the tent trembling as if caught in a storm. The whispers rose to a deafening roar, and Elias clapped his hands over his ears, his eyes locked on the figurine as it began to glow with an eerie, otherworldly light.
The last thing he saw before the darkness claimed him was the figurine’s face, its grimace twisting into what he could only describe as a smile.
description: Archaeological horror: a researcher uncovers a cursed artifact

text:
Charlotte Eastwick had always imagined her October would be filled with final wedding preparations and champagne toasts. Instead, she found herself walking along the rocky Maine coastline, trying to outpace memories of Devin that chased her like seagulls after scattered bread crumbs.
The breeze off the Atlantic carried the briny scent of seaweed and the distinctive tang of approaching autumn. Waves crashed against the weathered rocks below, sending up plumes of spray that caught the morning light. In Boston, the leaves would be turning brilliant shades of red and gold by now, but here in Kennebunkport, the coastal winds had already stripped many of the trees bare, leaving their branches to claw at the crystal-clear sky.
Charlie adjusted her grip on her beach umbrella, canvas bag, and the paperback she'd grabbed from the local bookstore that morning. The woman behind the counter had smiled knowingly when Charlie purchased both the romance novel and a bar of chocolate. “Bad breakup?” she'd asked. Charlie had only managed a weak smile in response. How could she explain that her perfect fiancé had turned out to be running a side business in infidelity? Or that his family had written her a check with enough zeros to make her shame feel exponential?
The rocky path opened onto Cleaves Cove Beach, and Charlie felt her shoulders relax at the sight of the empty stretch of sand. Perfect. The last thing she wanted was to make awkward small talk with tourists asking why she was at the beach in October.
She picked her way across the sand, noting how different it felt from the manicured beaches she was used to. This was wild, untamed shoreline, with smooth stones mixed into the sand and tangles of seaweed marking the tide line. Charlie found a relatively flat spot and began setting up her umbrella, cursing under her breath as the wind caught it and nearly yanked it from her hands.
After three attempts, she finally got the umbrella secured and spread out her towel underneath. The temperature hovered in the mid-sixties – warm enough in the sun, though the breeze held a bite that hinted at the winter to come. Charlie settled onto her towel and opened her book, determined to lose herself in someone else's romance rather than dwelling on the smoking ruins of her own.
She'd made it through exactly two paragraphs when a shadow fell across the page.
“Hey there.” The voice was deep, friendly, and carried just a hint of local accent. “Hate to interrupt your reading, but I should probably warn you – this stretch of beach is private property.”
Charlie tilted her head back, squinting against the sun. The man blocking her light was tall, broad-shouldered, and backlit like some kind of beachy demigod. As her eyes adjusted, she took in sun-bleached hair, tanned skin, and the kind of strong features that seemed carved by the same forces that had shaped the coastline.
“Oh God, I'm so sorry.” Charlie scrambled to her feet, almost taking out her umbrella in the process. “I didn't see any signs.”
“Easy there.” He caught the umbrella before it could become an impromptu projectile. “No harm done. The owners just get pretty territorial about their slice of paradise. They've been known to call the police on unsuspecting tourists.” His smile was warm, crinkling the corners of his eyes. “I'm Finn, by the way. Finn Morgan.”
“Charlie – well, Charlotte, but everyone calls me Charlie.” She brushed sand from her legs, suddenly very aware that she was wearing an ancient pair of denim shorts she'd packed purely for comfort.
“Tourist or local?” Finn asked, though something in his tone suggested he already knew the answer.
“That obvious, huh?” Charlie managed a self-deprecating smile. “I'm here for a week. Needed a change of scenery.”
“From?”
“Boston.” She hesitated, then added, “Where I was supposed to be getting married next weekend.”
Finn's eyebrows rose slightly. “Supposed to be?”
“Yeah.” Charlie focused on folding her towel, avoiding his gaze. “Turns out my fiancé believed monogamy was more of a suggestion than a requirement.”
“Shit.” The word carried genuine sympathy. “That's rough. I'm sorry.”
Charlie shrugged, aiming for casual and probably missing by a mile. “It is what it is. At least I found out before the wedding, right?”
“Still.” Finn studied her for a moment, then gestured down the beach. “Look, if you're wanting somewhere quiet to read, I know a spot that's actually open to the public. Better view too.”
Charlie hesitated. On one hand, she'd come here specifically to avoid people. On the other, there was something about Finn that put her at ease – maybe it was the way he carried himself, comfortable in his own skin in a way Devin never had been, for all his designer suits and carefully cultivated image.
“You're not going to lead me to some secluded spot and murder me, are you?” The question slipped out before she could stop it.
Finn laughed, the sound carrying over the crash of the waves. “Nah, murder's not really my thing. Too messy. Besides, I've got lobsters to catch later.” He nodded toward a boat moored further down the coast. “That's my girl there – the *Mary Rose*.”
“You're a lobsterman?” Charlie found herself falling into step beside him as they walked along the water's edge.
“Born and raised. Family business.” He glanced at her. “What about you? What do you do when you're not escaping wedding drama?”
“Graphic design. Mostly corporate stuff, logos, branding.” She didn't mention that she'd been about to launch her own firm, before everything imploded and Devin's family's hush money became too tempting to refuse. The NDA she'd signed felt like it was burning a hole in her back pocket, even though the actual document was locked in her desk drawer back home.
They rounded a bend in the coastline, and Charlie caught her breath. A small cove opened up before them, protected by rocky outcrops on either side. The water here was a deeper blue, and someone had arranged several large rocks into surprisingly comfortable-looking seats.
“This is gorgeous,” she said, meaning it.
“Local secret.” Finn grinned. “Well, semi-secret. The tourists usually stick to the main beaches.” He glanced up at the sky, which was still a brilliant, cloudless blue. “Just keep an eye on the weather. Storms can come up fast around here, especially this time of year. You don't want to get caught out when the wind shifts.”
Charlie nodded, already imagining how perfect this spot would be for reading. Or thinking. Or just existing without the weight of everything pressing down on her.
“I should get back to the boat,” Finn said. “But I'm sure I'll see you around. Small town and all that.”
“Thanks for the rescue.” Charlie smiled, surprised to find it didn't feel forced. “And the local intel.”
“Anytime.” He turned to go, then paused. “Oh, and Charlie? Your ex is an idiot.”
Before she could respond, he was walking away, his long strides eating up the sand. Charlie watched him go, feeling something warm unfurl in her chest – something that felt dangerously like hope.
With a small shake of her head, she set up her umbrella again and settled in with her book. But her mind kept wandering from the pages to the way Finn's eyes had crinkled when he smiled, and how his voice had wrapped around her nickname like he'd been saying it for years.
*Stop it*, she told herself firmly. She was here to heal, not to jump into another potential heartbreak. But as the waves crashed against the rocks and the October sun warmed her skin, Charlie found herself hoping she'd run into Finn Morgan again – preferably before the storms rolled in.
description: Beachy romance: a woman escapes her broken engagement to Maine

text:
Sarah Chen’s fingers hovered over the keyboard as Congressman James Barrett’s voice filled the room. He paced the office like a caged tiger, the sharp clap of his shoes against the polished hardwood punctuating his words. The fluorescent lights overhead cast a stark glow on the walls adorned with framed photos of him shaking hands with farmers, veterans, and children—the quintessential man of the people.
“The American people,” Barrett declared, emphasizing each syllable, “deserve to know how their tax dollars are being spent. Not tomorrow, not next year, but today.” He paused, his piercing blue eyes locking onto Sarah. “Too strong? Or does it hit the right note?”
Sarah glanced at the speech on her laptop, the cursor blinking in sync with her quickening pulse. “I think it’s good,” she said, her voice carefully measured. “It’s… commanding.”
Barrett nodded thoughtfully and resumed pacing, the script in his hand rustling like dry leaves. He had a way of moving that demanded attention, every gesture deliberate, every turn calculated.
“Commanding,” he repeated, testing the word. “But not too aggressive?”
“Not at all,” Sarah said, though she wasn’t entirely sure. He always sought her input, dissecting the cadence and rhythm of each line, but his questions left her feeling like she was being tested. She supposed it was flattering—a freshman aide whose opinion seemed to matter to a man on the brink of a presidential campaign. But it was also… odd.
“Let’s tweak the second half,” Barrett said, flipping through the pages. “What if we reframe it? Something like, ‘They have a right to demand transparency, because it’s their money.’ More personal. More immediate.”
“I’ll make the change,” Sarah said, typing quickly. The new line appeared on her screen, and she read it back to him.
Barrett closed his eyes, mouthing the words as if tasting them. Then he opened them, sharp and bright. “That’ll do. Let’s move on.”
Sarah adjusted her glasses and scrolled down. Her job was simple: refine, tweak, polish. And yet, every time they worked through a speech, she felt that nagging unease creep up her spine. Barrett’s public persona was magnetic, his conviction palpable. But behind closed doors, he was… different. Not insincere, exactly, but detached, as though the fiery speeches were just lines in a play he’d been cast in.
Barrett stopped suddenly, mid-pace. “Sarah, what do you think about the word ‘demand’? Too harsh? Would ‘expect’ work better, or does that weaken it?”
She hesitated, considering the nuance. “I think ‘demand’ has more weight. It’s stronger. ‘Expect’ feels a bit… passive.”
He nodded, running a hand through his perfectly combed hair. “Good point. Demand it is.” He returned to the speech, but this time his voice softened, almost reflective. “You know, sometimes I wonder how much people really care about this stuff. Do you think they’re paying attention?”
The question caught her off guard. “I think… I think they care when someone like you makes them care. You have a way of connecting with people.”
Barrett smiled, but it didn’t quite reach his eyes. “That’s kind of you to say.”
Her phone buzzed, jolting her out of her thoughts. She winced, fumbling to silence it. Barrett stopped mid-sentence, turning to her with an arched brow.
“Sorry,” she stammered. “I should’ve muted it.”
To her surprise, he smiled. “Don’t worry about it. I needed a break anyway.” He set the script down and stretched, rolling his shoulders. “I’m going to grab some coffee. Take fifteen minutes. You’ve earned it.”
“Thanks,” Sarah said, relieved. He disappeared through the door, leaving her alone in the quiet hum of the office. She picked up her phone and glanced at the screen. A text from an unknown number.
*Your boss isn’t who you think he is. If you want the truth, check under the bush near the Senate Fountain. Look for a plastic bag caught on it.*
Sarah stared at the message, her pulse quickening. A prank? Some kind of joke? She glanced at the door, half expecting Barrett to walk back in, smirking at her gullibility. But the text… there was something about it that felt off. Too deliberate. Too pointed.
She considered reporting it. That was the logical thing to do. But curiosity prickled at the edges of her mind, urging her to find out more. Before she could second-guess herself, she deleted the message, closed her laptop, and grabbed her coat.
The air outside was crisp, carrying the faint tang of exhaust and the murmur of distant traffic. The Senate Fountain loomed ahead, its water sparkling under the floodlights. Sarah’s heels clicked against the pavement as she approached, her eyes scanning the bushes that lined the fountain.
And then she saw it. A crumpled plastic bag, caught on the low branches of a bush. Her heart thudded as she crouched, glancing around to make sure no one was watching. The area seemed deserted, but her skin prickled with the sensation of being observed.
Her fingers brushed against something hard and smooth beneath the bush. She pulled it free: a Ziploc bag, sealed tightly, with a thumb drive inside. Her breath caught as she turned it over in her hands. No markings, no note, just the drive.
For a moment, she hesitated. This was insane. She was an aide to one of the most prominent congressmen in the country, not some spy in a political thriller. But the weight of the drive in her hand felt undeniable, like a stone dropped into a still pond, sending ripples through her carefully ordered world.
She slipped it into her pocket and stood, brushing off her coat. As she walked back toward the Dirksen Building, her mind raced. Who had sent the text? What could be on the drive? And why her?
When she reached Barrett’s office, he was already back, coffee in hand, his expression as calm and collected as ever. “Ready to pick up where we left off?” he asked, his tone warm, easy.
Sarah nodded, forcing a smile. But as she sat down and opened her laptop, the drive in her pocket felt like it was burning a hole through the fabric, heavy with secrets she wasn’t sure she wanted to uncover.
description: Political thriller: a staffer questions her congressman's authenticity

text:
The wind, sharp and insistent, whipped across the exposed mountainside, carrying with it the scent of damp earth and distant pine. Dr. Elias Vinter hunched deeper into his worn Barbour jacket, the collar pulled high around his ears. He glanced at the bruised grey sky, a familiar knot of anxiety tightening in his stomach. The weather had been threatening for days, and the locals’ warnings about sudden, violent storms in these northern Norwegian mountains echoed in his mind.
Elias straightened, pushing his worries aside. This dig, this remote Viking ship burial nestled high in the unforgiving landscape, was his focus. It had to be. His career had stalled, a dry spell of publications stretching into years. His lectures at the university had become rote, a weary repetition of well-worn material. And then there was Ingrid, his wife, the specter of divorce hanging heavy between them. This discovery, this excavation, was his chance to prove himself, to salvage something from the wreckage of his life.
The site itself was a hive of activity. A team of students, their faces flushed with exertion and the chill air, carefully brushed away layers of earth, revealing more of the long, elegant lines of the buried ship. Local workers, their faces weathered and wise, moved deftly amongst them, their knowledge of the terrain and the unpredictable weather invaluable. The rhythmic clang of trowels against stone, the low murmur of conversations in both Norwegian and English, and the ever-present sigh of the wind created a constant, almost hypnotic hum.
Elias’s current task was meticulously documenting the area surrounding the ship's stern. He knelt on a small, portable stool, his fingers numb with cold despite his gloves. The fine, grey soil clung to everything, coating his hands, his clothes, even the lenses of his glasses. He squinted, carefully brushing away another layer of dirt from a section of what appeared to be a collapsed timber. The air was thick with the earthy smell of damp soil and the fainter, almost metallic tang of ancient iron.
A sudden rumble echoed through the valley, deeper and more resonant than the usual gusts of wind. Elias looked up, his gaze drawn to the darkening clouds that swirled above the peaks. A flash of lightning illuminated the scene for a split second, followed by a low growl of thunder. The wind intensified, tugging at the tarpaulins that partially covered the dig site.
“Looks like we’re in for it,” a voice boomed beside him. It was Bjørn, one of the local workers, a man built like a bear with a booming laugh and eyes that seemed to read the weather like an open book. “The old gods are restless today.”
Elias nodded, a shiver running down his spine that had nothing to do with the cold. He glanced at the other workers, who were beginning to move with a renewed urgency, securing the tarpaulins and gathering their tools.
As he turned back to his work, a faint glint of green caught his eye. It was nestled in the fine dust near where he had been working, almost invisible against the grey soil. Curiosity piqued, Elias leaned closer, carefully brushing away the remaining dirt. He thought at first it might be a shard of green glass or perhaps a small, weathered jewel.
He was so engrossed in his discovery that he almost didn’t notice the first fat drops of rain that began to fall. The wind howled, and another, closer clap of thunder shook the ground beneath them.
“Elias! We need to go!” It was Dr. Astrid Olsen, his colleague and the lead archaeologist on the dig, her voice sharp with urgency. “The locals are saying this could turn nasty. We need to secure the site and get down to the village.”
Elias glanced up, his eyes widening as he took in the scene. The sky had darkened dramatically, and the rain was coming down harder now, a steady drumming on the tarpaulins. The other workers were already scrambling towards the waiting Jeeps parked at the edge of the site.
“Just a minute,” Elias called back, his voice barely audible above the wind and rain. “I think I’ve found something.” He gestured to the small area he was working on, where the rain was now washing away more of the dirt, revealing more of the green object.
“Elias, this is serious!” Astrid shouted, her face etched with worry. “The locals say there’s a risk of mudslides with this kind of rain. We have to leave now.”
He knew she was right. He could see the urgency in the faces of the local workers, their eyes fixed on the darkening sky and the rapidly swelling streams that snaked down the mountainside. But something held him rooted to the spot. The glint of green had become more distinct, revealing the contours of what appeared to be a small figurine.
“I’ll just mark this find,” he said, his voice strained. “I’ll be right behind you. I’ll follow in my Jeep.”
Astrid hesitated, her expression torn between concern and exasperation. Finally, with a sigh, she turned and hurried towards the waiting vehicles. “Don’t be long!” she called back over her shoulder.
Elias watched them go, the red tail lights of the Jeeps disappearing down the winding mountain road. The rain was coming down in torrents now, soaking him to the bone. He barely noticed. His entire attention was focused on the figurine.
As the rain continued to wash away the soil, the figure became clearer. It was crudely carved, not of stone or metal, but of some dark, almost black material. It appeared to be a figure of a woman, though the details were worn and indistinct. The glint of green he had seen earlier was now revealed to be two small, cloudy green gems embedded in the figure’s head, giving it an eerie, blind stare.
Elias felt a strange pull towards the figurine, an almost unsettling fascination. He began to carefully work it free from the earth, his fingers tracing the rough contours of its form. He found himself thinking of it as “her,” a strange, almost possessive thought.
As he gently loosened the figurine from the clinging soil, he discovered that she was mounted on the back of a small, muscular-looking warhorse. The details were crude, but the power of the animal was still evident.
The wind howled, and a sudden, ominous clattering sound made him jump. He looked up to see a nearby pile of stones beginning to slide down the mountainside, dislodged by the relentless rain. The ground beneath him was becoming saturated, the small streams around the dig site turning into rushing torrents.
He looked back down at the figurine, his jaw suddenly aching. He realized he had been holding a broad, almost manic grin for some time, without even realizing it. He wasn’t sure how long he had been sitting there, in the pouring rain, grinning at nothing.
With a jolt, he snapped out of his trance. The storm was reaching a fever pitch. The rain was a blinding sheet, and the wind threatened to tear the remaining tarpaulins from their moorings. He had to get out of there.
Carefully, almost reverently, he wrapped the figurine in a sopping wet towel that he had been using to clean his tools. He shoved it into his jacket pocket, the cold, damp object pressing against his chest.
He scrambled to his feet, his muscles stiff and aching. He waded through the mud towards his Jeep, the wind and rain buffeting him from all sides. As he fumbled with the keys, he knew one thing with absolute certainty. He wasn’t going to tell anyone about this find. This was his, and his alone.
description: Archaeological horror: a dig in Norway yields a disturbing figurine

text:
Commander Helena Vasquez felt the familiar weight of acceleration press her deeper into the command chair as the *Retribution's Blade* completed its final transition jump. The massive dreadnought's quantum displacement drive wound down with a subsonic hum that resonated through the ship's titanium-carbide hull, a sound that had become as comforting to her as a heartbeat over the past eighteen months.
“Jump complete, ma'am,” reported Lieutenant Chen from the navigation console, his neural interface crown flickering with data streams. “We're holding position at the Meridian system's heliopause, approximately forty-seven AU from the primary star.”
Helena's tactical display materialized in her peripheral vision, courtesy of her own military-grade neural implant. The Meridian system spread out before her in three-dimensional holographic detail—a yellow dwarf star surrounded by eleven planets, three of which had been terraformed by the Hegemony Colonial Administration over the past century. More importantly, the system contained the largest concentration of quantum metallic hydrogen outside of Earth's home system, making it strategically invaluable to both the Terran Federation and their enemies in the Collective States.
“Sensor sweep complete,” announced Chief Warrant Officer Patel from the detection station. “I'm reading approximately two hundred vessels in-system, ma'am. Breakdown as follows: fifty-seven civilian cargo haulers, thirty-four automated mining platforms, eighteen patrol craft...” She paused, her expression darkening. “And eighty-nine vessels of unknown configuration holding position in high orbit around Meridian Prime.”
Helena's jaw tightened. Eighty-nine ships was far more than intelligence had predicted. The Collective's Fifth Fleet was supposed to be scattered across three systems, not concentrated here in overwhelming force. Either their intelligence had been fatally flawed, or they'd walked into a trap.
“Classification on those unknowns?” she asked, though she suspected she already knew the answer.
“Analyzing now, Commander.” Patel's fingers danced across her holographic interface, neural pathways processing terabytes of sensor data in milliseconds. “Confirmed: Collective signatures. I'm reading twelve heavy cruisers, twenty-four destroyers, fifteen frigates, and... God's blood, ma'am. Thirty-eight dreadnoughts.”
The bridge fell silent except for the ambient hum of life support systems and the distant thrum of the fusion reactors. Thirty-eight dreadnoughts represented enough firepower to glass a planet's surface or shatter an entire fleet. Helena's own task force consisted of just four dreadnoughts, eight heavy cruisers, and sixteen destroyers—formidable by any standard, but woefully outgunned against what awaited them in Meridian space.
“Time to fleet rendezvous?” Helena asked, her voice steady despite the cold calculation running through her enhanced cognitive processes.
“Admiral Kowalski's Third Fleet is still fourteen hours out,” replied Chen. “The Fourth Fleet won't arrive for another twenty-six hours.”
Twenty-six hours. The Collective fleet could reduce the orbital habitats and planetary settlements to radioactive debris long before reinforcements arrived. Helena's tactical subroutines ran probability analyses at superhuman speed, each simulation ending in catastrophic failure. Unless...
“Ms. Patel, what's the configuration of their fleet positioning?”
The sensor officer's brow furrowed as she processed the question. “They're maintaining a standard orbital defense grid, ma'am. Overlapping fields of fire, mutual support clusters, with the dreadnoughts forming the primary defensive perimeter.”
“Standard doctrine,” Helena murmured, more to herself than to her crew. The Collective military operated with rigid adherence to established tactical principles—a strength in most situations, but potentially exploitable by an opponent willing to think outside conventional parameters.
She activated her command neural link, establishing encrypted communications with the other vessels in her task force. Captain Morrison of the *Sovereign's Wrath*, Captain Zhang aboard the *Democratic Fury*, and Captain Al-Rashid commanding the *People's Justice* appeared as ghostly holographic figures around her chair.
“Situation report, Commanders,” Helena began without preamble. “We're facing a Collective fleet nearly twice our projected strength. Recommendations?”
Captain Morrison, a grizzled veteran of the Titan War, shook his head grimly. “Ma'am, with respect, we should consider withdrawal. Even with our technological advantages, those odds are insurmountable in a direct engagement.”
“Agreed,” added Captain Zhang. “Our quantum torpedo loadout gives us superior firepower per vessel, but thirty-eight dreadnoughts is simply too much mass to overcome.”
Captain Al-Rashid remained silent for a moment, his enhanced eyes processing tactical data at accelerated rates. “There might be another option,” he said finally. “The Collective's positioning suggests they're preparing for a conventional fleet engagement—they expect us to advance in standard formation and attempt to break their defensive perimeter.”
“Go on,” Helena prompted.
“What if we don't give them that fight? The asteroid field in the outer system provides excellent cover, and our stealth capabilities are superior to theirs. We could conduct a series of hit-and-run attacks, forcing them to disperse their formation.”
Helena's tactical implants were already running simulations based on Al-Rashid's suggestion. The probability matrices looked marginally better, though still heavily weighted against success. However, there was another factor to consider—one that her fellow commanders couldn't access through their standard military hardware.
Deep within Helena's consciousness, beyond the reach of conventional neural interfaces, lay her most closely guarded secret: a prototype artificial intelligence core, a gift from her former lover and current enemy, Dr. Marcus Chen of the Collective Research Division. The AI, which she'd named Athena, possessed computational capabilities that exceeded even military-grade quantum processors.
*Analysis, Athena,* she thought.
*Fleet engagement probability of success: twelve percent,* came the immediate response, transmitted directly to her consciousness through quantum-encrypted channels. *However, alternative tactical options available. Collective fleet positioning reveals vulnerability: their command structure relies on centralized coordination through the flagship “Inexorable Will.” Decapitation strike could create sufficient chaos to allow successful engagement.*
Helena's pulse quickened. A decapitation strike—the targeted elimination of enemy command and control—was theoretically possible with their stealth capabilities and quantum weaponry. But it would require precise timing and likely sacrifice at least one of her vessels to achieve.
“Gentlemen,” she said aloud, “I'm transmitting updated tactical parameters. We're going to attempt something unconventional.”
As the holographic tactical display updated with her proposed battle plan, she watched her fellow commanders' expressions shift from skepticism to amazement to grim determination. The plan was audacious, bordering on suicidal, but it offered their only realistic chance of victory.
“Commander,” Captain Morrison said slowly, “this requires one of our dreadnoughts to essentially commit suicide by ramming through their defensive perimeter. Which vessel are you proposing for that role?”
Helena's smile held no warmth. “The *Retribution's Blade* will have that honor, Captain. My ship has the most advanced stealth systems and quantum shielding. If anyone can punch through their defenses and reach the Collective flagship, it's us.”
The next several hours passed in a blur of preparation. Quantum torpedoes were loaded and armed, stealth systems calibrated to maximum efficiency, and shield generators pushed beyond their normal operational parameters. Helena walked through her ship's corridors, speaking with crew members, ensuring that everyone understood both the mission's importance and its likely cost.
As she stood in the observation deck, watching the distant stars of Meridian space, Helena felt Athena's presence in her mind once more.
*Second thoughts, Commander?*
*None,* Helena replied without hesitation. *The Collective has killed too many civilians, enslaved too many worlds. If this is where we make our stand, then so be it.*
*Your probability of survival is approximately fifteen percent.*
*Then I'll have to be very lucky, won't I?*
The AI's equivalent of laughter rippled through her consciousness. *Indeed. Though I suspect luck will have little to do with what happens next.*
Helena returned to the bridge as the ship's chronometer showed just two hours until the attack commenced. Her crew moved with the practiced efficiency of veterans, each person focused on their assigned tasks with the knowledge that failure meant not just their own deaths, but the deaths of millions of innocents on the planets below.
“All stations report ready, Commander,” announced her executive officer, Commander Sarah Okafor. “Stealth systems are operating at peak efficiency, and the quantum torpedo bays are fully loaded.”
“Very good, XO.” Helena settled into her command chair, feeling the neural interface establish its connections. Around her, the bridge hummed with barely contained energy—both technological and human.
“Open channel to the fleet,” she ordered.
“Channel open, ma'am.”
Helena drew a deep breath, knowing that her next words would likely be among the last she ever spoke. “This is Commander Vasquez to all vessels. Today we face an enemy that believes overwhelming force guarantees victory. They're about to learn otherwise. Execute Operation Meridian Gambit on my mark. And remember—we fight not for glory, but for the millions of souls counting on us to see another sunrise.”
She closed the channel and activated the ship's internal communications. “All hands, this is the Captain. Prepare for combat operations. May fortune favor the bold.”
The *Retribution's Blade* began its final approach toward the Collective fleet, her quantum drives running silent, her hull nearly invisible against the cosmic background. Behind her, the rest of Helena's task force moved into position, their own roles in the deadly ballet about to unfold.
As the distance closed and targeting solutions began to form, Helena felt a strange sense of peace settle over her. Whatever came next, she would face it with her eyes open and her conscience clear. The fate of the Meridian system—and perhaps the entire war—now rested in the hands of four ships and their crews, racing through the void toward a rendezvous with destiny.
