text:
The cool, thin air of a late autumn morning bit at Liam's cheeks as he hurried through the cobbled streets of Hearthwood. It was a crisp, clear day, the kind that promised frost by nightfall. The sun, a pale coin in the eastern sky, cast long, brittle shadows of the town's thatched rooftops and skeletal oak trees. The scent of woodsmoke, wet earth, and fresh-baked bread hung heavy in the air, a comforting and familiar perfume that had been the backdrop to all his twenty years of life.
Hearthwood was a town of no particular consequence, nestled in a wide, verdant valley at the very edge of the Kingdom of Aethelgard. It was far enough from the capital of Northward to be largely forgotten by the King's Court and close enough to the northern mountains to have a population of hardy, independent-minded people. For as long as anyone could remember, Hearthwood had been a quiet place of farmers, tradesmen, and simple folk, and Liam, the apprentice to the town's elderly Scholar, wouldn't have had it any other way.
His master, an old man named Elara, was both the town's loremaster and its healer, a rare combination that spoke to a quiet wisdom far older than the mountains that guarded the valley. Liam's work was a steady and unhurried rhythm of grinding herbs, transcribing ancient texts, and organizing the endless shelves of scrolls in Elara's library. It was a life of quiet purpose, one that had seemed destined to continue until the end of his days.
This morning, however, there was a new kind of urgency in his step. The weekly delivery of supplies from the capital was late. It was never late. In all his time as Elara's apprentice, the delivery carts had arrived at dawn on the third day of the week, without fail. He had gone to the town gates an hour ago and found only the empty, rutted tracks of the King's Road, disappearing into the mist-shrouded distance.
He arrived at Elara's cottage and pushed open the heavy oak door. A warm rush of air, smelling of chamomile and old parchment, greeted him. Elara was sitting at his large, cluttered table, a quill poised over a half-finished parchment. His white hair, thin and fine, seemed to catch the lamplight like a faint halo. He looked up, his pale blue eyes, as clear as a mountain stream, regarding Liam with a knowing calm.
“They didn’t come, Master,” Liam said, his breath still catching in his throat from the brisk walk.
Elara nodded slowly, a small, weary sigh escaping his lips. “I had a feeling they would not.”
Liam frowned, pulling a stool up to the table. “How could you know?”
The old man simply tapped the parchment with his quill. “The message I am writing, Liam. It is a report of all the strange things that have been happening this past month. The wild deer have vanished from the southern woods. The river fish swim in circles. The air has a… a different flavor to it.” He paused, his gaze fixed on some far-off point beyond the walls of the cottage. “The balance is shifting, my boy. There are whispers on the wind.”
“Whispers? What whispers?”
“Of an army, they say. One that marches without banners, from the east.”
Liam felt a cold knot tighten in his stomach. The east. That was the Great Dividing Range, the impassable wall of peaks that separated Aethelgard from the uncharted lands beyond. Nothing came from the east. It was a place of myth and legend, home only to ancient spirits and the echoes of a forgotten time.
“That’s impossible, Master. No one has ever crossed the Divide.”
“Perhaps,” Elara said, his voice soft but firm. “But an army does not need to cross the Divide if it already waits on the other side. Do you remember the legends of the Rift?”
Liam’s blood ran cold. The Rift. A tale Elara had told him countless times during long winter nights. It was said that many centuries ago, a tear in the very fabric of reality had opened between their world and another. A war had been fought to close it, a war so terrible it was only spoken of in hushed tones. The last of the wizards had sacrificed themselves to seal the tear, and a great silence had fallen over the land.
“But that’s just a story, Master. A cautionary tale for children.”
“Is it?” Elara’s eyes held a deep sadness. “The King’s Court would scoff at the thought, but the land itself knows. The animals know. And the trees know, if you listen closely enough.” He pushed the quill and inkwell toward Liam. “I need you to take this message to Northward. The King’s Council must be made aware. Something is coming, Liam. I feel it in my bones. It’s a great darkness, and it begins with a great silence.”
A sense of dread, cold and unfamiliar, settled over Liam. He had never been beyond Hearthwood. The King’s Road stretched out for ten days of hard travel to the capital. The journey was long and perilous even in the best of times, with bandits and wild beasts to contend with. But he saw the fear in his master's eyes, a fear he had never seen before.
“I’ll leave at once, Master.”
Elara placed a gentle, bony hand on Liam’s shoulder. “Good. Be swift, but be careful. Do not draw attention to yourself. The road is not as empty as it seems.” He then reached under his table and pulled out a small, well-worn satchel. “Take this. It has enough food and water for the first few days, and a small purse of coins for your journey. There are also a few extra scrolls—just in case you encounter someone who can provide you with information.”
Liam took the satchel, his fingers brushing against a hard object within. He opened it and saw a worn leather-bound book, its pages yellowed with age. “The Book of Lore?” he whispered. This was Elara’s most prized possession, a compendium of forgotten spells, ancient history, and healing secrets.
“I want you to have it,” Elara said, a faint smile gracing his lips. “It has been my companion for many years, and I believe it is time for it to find a new home. You have a good heart, Liam, and a thirst for knowledge. You will be a great Scholar someday.”
As Liam stepped out of the cottage, the world seemed to have changed. The town that had always felt so secure now felt fragile. The familiar scents of woodsmoke and fresh bread now seemed tinged with the scent of fear. The sun, once a comforting coin in the sky, now seemed to offer no warmth at all. He had always been a simple apprentice, a boy who thought his biggest concern would be remembering the names of obscure medicinal herbs. Now, he carried a book of secrets and a dire warning for a king he had only heard of in stories. He was on the brink of an adventure he had never asked for, on a road that would take him far from the only home he had ever known.
He looked back at the town one last time, at the spire of the temple and the smoke rising from a hundred chimneys. It was a world of peaceful ordinariness, one he had always taken for granted. He wondered if he would ever see it again, or if the whispers on the wind were the last breath of the world he knew. He took a deep breath, fastened his satchel, and turned onto the King’s Road, his young heart pounding with a mixture of fear and a strange, exhilarating sense of destiny.
description: High fantasy: an apprentice carries a warning of approaching darkness

text:
The air smells like ash.
It’s in my lungs every time I take a breath, hanging thick and bitter like the taste of burnt metal. The city, once a gleaming monument to human ambition, is now a crumbling relic. What was once a proud skyline is nothing more than a jagged outline against a sky gone permanently gray. The towers that used to pierce the clouds are now hollowed-out shells, their windows shattered like broken teeth. The streets, once alive with the hustle of thousands, are now silent—except for the occasional creak of metal or the distant clatter of fallen debris.
I pause at the edge of the bridge, where the dark river below churns with the weight of a thousand forgotten secrets. The water used to sparkle, or so they say. Now, it’s a slow-moving sludge, carrying the weight of everything that’s gone wrong.
“You’ve been staring at that river for too long,” Kiera says, her voice cutting through the quiet like a blade. She steps up beside me, her boots making no sound on the cracked concrete. I don’t have to turn to know she’s there. I can feel her presence in the tension between us. She’s always been good at that.
“I’m thinking,” I murmur, running my fingers along the jagged edge of the bridge’s rusted rail. The thought of the past feels almost surreal now—like some distant memory I can’t quite reach. The world that used to be is fading, replaced by something darker, something I never asked for.
She smirks, but there’s no humor in it. “Don’t overthink it. You’ll make your brain rot faster than the air out here.”
I give her a half-smile, though it doesn’t reach my eyes. Kiera’s always been blunt. It’s part of what keeps us alive, I guess. The bluntness, the hard edges, the refusal to feel too much. Feeling too much gets people killed.
We stand there for a while, the city’s broken silence pressing down on us. It’s hard to remember what it was like before the Collapse—before the world burned itself to the ground in a haze of greed and apathy. But there are moments, fleeting as they are, when I almost do.
“Do you ever wonder if it was worth it?” I ask, my voice barely above a whisper.
Kiera stiffens beside me, the air around her suddenly thick with tension. “Of course it wasn’t worth it,” she says quickly, like the words have been rehearsed too many times. “But we can’t waste time thinking about that now. We’ve got enough problems as it is.” Her gaze flicks toward the distant horizon, where the towering smoke from the factories marks the edge of our world.
“Right.”
I swallow the lump that rises in my throat, trying not to think about the weight of what we’ve lost. I can feel it in the pit of my stomach, that ache of knowing we’ll never go back to what we were. The world as it was is gone, and with it, so much of what made me… me.
A loud crack sounds in the distance, followed by the unmistakable thrum of engines. Kiera doesn’t even flinch, but I can feel the hair on the back of my neck stand up. It’s not the first time we’ve heard that sound, but every time, it sends a cold shiver through my bones. The Patrol is out there. And when they’re out there, it means trouble.
“We should go,” I say, already turning toward the shadowed alley that runs parallel to the bridge.
Kiera hesitates for just a moment, and I glance back. Her gaze is locked on the horizon, her face unreadable. I know she’s thinking about the same thing I am: The Patrol doesn’t just wander aimlessly. They’re looking for something—or someone.
She catches my eye and nods sharply. “Let’s move.”
We slip into the shadows, blending into the wreckage of a city that used to have a name, a life, a future. But now it’s all just ruins. The only future left is the one we’re making for ourselves, step by dangerous step.
I don’t know how long we’ll last, but I do know this: The moment you stop running is the moment you’re as good as dead. And no matter how much I wish otherwise, I’m not ready to die.
Not today.
Not yet.
description: Dystopian YA: survivors navigate a ruined city

text:
Look at this foolish woman, charging through a blizzard in the dead of night, her horse floundering through chest-high snowdrifts as she rides like the devil himself is at her heels. Two women, actually—her maid Cecelia is too brave and loyal for her own good.
Though I say “woman,” in that moment she might as well have been a girl. We're always youngest in our most desperate moments, aren't we?
That's me, or rather it was me, a lifetime ago. Racing to save the man I loved.
On Christmas Eve, of all nights.
But forget my foolishness for a moment. Let's spare a thought for that poor horse. His name was Jonquil, and he deserved none of this. He hadn't married a man who tumbled from disaster to disaster, nor had he decided he couldn't bear to be a widow and taken matters into his own hands. He could have bucked me into a snowbank and trotted off to the nearest village, where some peasant would have welcomed him as a mysterious Christmas gift. Instead, he fought his way through those drifts, probably whinnying *Winnie, what manner of madness have you dragged us into this time?* under his breath.
Oh, come now, I hear you thinking, how perilous could a snowy ride truly be? Well, before you grow too skeptical of my predicament, remember that in my day, you could die from a paper cut. Everything was trying to kill us. Modern folk hear about our average lifespans and assume that in my era, you were ancient at thirty. That's not how averages work, dear reader. You were still in the bloom of adulthood at thirty, and we had our share of septuagenarians and octogenarians, even a handful who reached their nineties. We didn't age faster than you do—we simply died younger. If plague or wounds or brigands didn't claim us, politics stood ready on the scaffold with a bloody axe in hand.
Don't fret—she'll reach London safely, though it was madness to attempt a month-long, three-hundred-and-fifty-mile journey through the brutal Scottish winter. At least this fool was hardy, even if the ordeal took its toll on her health. She'll make it to the court of George I, that Protestant pretender, where she'll plead for her husband's life while the king ignores her. She won't surrender when she's dragged across the tiles of his courtroom, clinging to his robes, any more than she gave up in the snow and dark and biting wind.
“Never trust a Scot,” Catherine Walpole sneered while her monarch tried to slink away, with me clinging to his sleeve like a determined burr. “She's probably got a dagger hidden up there.”
Up your sleeve is where you hide tricks, not dirks, you silly English bint. Not that you'd know, with not a thought in your outrageously bewigged head beyond fripperies and jewels and your next liaison. What could you know of desperation? My knife was at my belt, naturally, though I had no real hope of using it. I was already contemplating, since this approach wasn't bearing fruit, what other items one might conceal in one's clothing. *Vestis virum facit*, after all.
Perhaps she was wiser than I gave her credit for, with her obsession over dresses. Used properly, a good gown can accomplish what an army cannot.
Was he worth all this effort, you're wondering, before you've heard even half the tale?
I've been called calculating, but the mathematics of love exceed my skills. I honestly couldn't say. He brought me almost all my misery, and I wouldn't change a moment of it.
We were young when we met—well, not by the standards of our time. I was nineteen, which was hardly young to be married, though I'm not convinced that made my judgment any sounder.
If you're curious what won me over, well, a proper Catholic girl doesn't kiss and tell, but mercy me: that *kiss*.
We were at the French court, and I was quite the charmer, so I had plenty of points of comparison—though I'll leave those liaisons dangereuses to your imagination. I was discreet, naturally, being neither fool nor flirt.
We kissed, I fell under his spell, and the rest—the parts that matter far less than you'd think—lies scattered through the history books. Reader, I married him.
His name was William. William and Winifred. Willy and Winnie—perfectly darling, isn't it? Or Will and Win, which paints us as quite the power couple. Never mind that his perpetual weakness of will landed us in one scrape after another, leaving me to manufacture victories where I could. Yet whenever I tried to be firm with him, he'd turn those sweet eyes on me, and I'd see again the boy I'd kissed in the French court, and my good sense would desert me entirely.
Depending on your perspective, I was either doomed by my family history to the sort of trouble he brought me, or I'd witnessed enough of it firsthand that I should have known better.
My father spent six bitter years in the Tower of London, caught in the anti-Catholic hysteria of his day. They believed he'd plotted to overthrow the British throne. According to the gossips, my mother hatched some ill-conceived scheme to free him and got herself arrested in the bargain, though they were both eventually released.
The truth? My mother's only crime was an excess of kindness. She gave money to Catholic prisoners, sending it through her midwife. But the midwife got entangled with a man called Thomas Dangerfield, who lost his heart (metaphorically) to my mother's almoner. When his affections weren't returned, he fabricated an entire Catholic conspiracy against the English throne just to implicate her. My mother nearly lost her head (literally) before the truth came to light.
Let that be a lesson: never trust a man with “danger” in his name.
Children should strive to surpass their parents' failures, so instead of being an innocent freed from the Tower after being falsely accused of participating in a fake Catholic plot against the King of England, Willie and I participated in a real Catholic uprising against the king of England, attempting to install a Scottish Catholic king in his place. Not to brag, but we got away Scot-free.
My parents weren't the only poor role models in matters of sense and survival. The year after my marriage, my older brother languished in Ghent, too ill to travel after being implicated in—you'll never guess—a Catholic plot to overthrow the British throne. You might recognize Ghent—it's where John of Gaunt hailed from, one of the men who started this whole king-switching business. From my current lofty perspective of being dead, I can tell you that in retrospect, we probably should have simply weathered the snowballing disaster that was Richard II rather than replacing him, given the avalanche of troubles that well-intentioned endeavor ultimately caused. But hindsight is ever eagle-eyed, isn't it?
Speaking of snowballs...
Let's return to that woman on her horse, in the endless darkness and cold and whirling snow, on Christmas Eve.
We'll get to all the history that brought her there, and everything that followed, but she was still close enough to home that she could have turned back and let Providence handle events. That was the moment, her heart quailing as the cold and hunger truly took hold and poor faithful Jonquil stumbled in the snow as though he might not reach shelter before winter claimed them all, that she decided what mattered most.
I apologize. I've just realized I haven't properly introduced her. Me. Being dead does tend to muddle both your sense of time and your manners.
My name is Lady Winifred Maxwell, née Herbert, Countess of Nithsdale.
I'm best known for breaking my husband, William Maxwell, 5th Earl of Nithsdale, out of the Tower of London, but there's far more to me than that.
And beneath it all—the sartorial shell-games and popish plots, the midnight rides and French intrigues and long years in exile—this is, at its heart, a love story.
description: Historical romance: Lady Winifred's daring midnight ride

text:
It was a sunny Thursday morning in April, and Detective Benjamin Singer was attending a lecture for the first time in decades, daydreaming about murder.
To be fair, the setting practically begged for wandering thoughts. The lecture hall resided in a faux-medieval edifice with a mournful, ecclesiastical air, clearly built in an era when architecture aspired to elevate the mind. Cloudy, gothic-arched windows framed by wisteria vines gave the illusion of flouncy green-and-purple curtains, their distortion from age adding an ethereal touch. Inside, ancient radiators wheezed like asthmatic giants, producing a soothing white noise that blended with the faint rhythm of tapping laptop keys. The air carried the warm, dusty scent of sun-heated stone and paper—a distinct aroma of old academia.
It was the perfect environment for a daydream, a meditation, or even a nap—not for lack of interest but because it was so serene.
“In the premodern world,” Professor Green intoned, “justice wasn’t about rehabilitation. That’s a modern notion, rooted in Western individualism. Back then, the criminal wasn’t seen as an individual to be corrected but as a problem with the community. A wound to be cleansed. Which approach sounds better to you?”
Green paused, his question more rhetorical than probing. The students continued tapping, their focus trained on their screens.
“It might seem kinder,” he continued, “this sense of collective responsibility, as though they weren’t blaming the criminal. But in truth, they didn’t care about the criminal as a person. The reasons behind the act—starvation, revenge, desperation—meant nothing. They simply wanted to erase the stain.”
Singer, half-listening, let the words weave through his thoughts. He was surprised by how much he was enjoying the lecture—by how comfortable he felt sitting in this cathedral of learning. A small part of him wondered if he’d wasted his time in college.
In his youth, no one had accused Benny Singer of being “wise beyond his years” or an “old soul.” College for him had been a blur of football games, beer, awkward dates, and dehydration headaches. He’d gone because it was what middle-class kids did, and because his parents, devout in their belief in education, insisted on it. They couldn’t ensure he’d absorb any learning, but they’d fulfilled their part by sending him.
Now, though, he’d grown into an anomaly—a man who, amid the machismo of the police force, had transformed into a sensitive, bookish soul. In his British mother’s term, he’d reached “middage,” a stage where he fancied himself as having a professorial air. He wasn’t bold enough to ask his colleagues if they’d agree, but the thought warmed him nonetheless.
Today, however, he wasn’t here for nostalgia. He was here to work. Professor Green, an expert on ancient justice, had been recommended to help him decode a peculiar piece of evidence in his latest case: a mutilated antique volume in Greek found beside a murder victim.
The victim, an antiquarian of considerable means, might have called himself “comfortable,” though these days that level of wealth seemed modest compared to the riches of tech tycoons. He’d died on the eve of his 97th birthday, surrounded by family members who were ostensibly there to celebrate—but Singer suspected, mostly to squabble over his estate.
The death was an intriguing locked-room puzzle. After announcing during dinner that he planned to change his will, the elderly man had retired to his bedroom and locked the door. By the next afternoon, when he hadn’t emerged, his assistant forced her way in and found him dead.
The autopsy revealed a lethal cocktail of unprescribed sleeping pills and narcotics, administered via injection in a spot the frail old man couldn’t have reached on his own. Security footage showed no one approaching the door, and the only key to the room was found in the victim’s nightstand. It was as though murder had walked through walls.
Yet, that wasn’t the most curious detail. Someone had placed coins over the man’s eyes and rested a mutilated antique book on his chest—a cognac-colored leather volume with a blood-red hand emblazoned on the cover. The book’s pages had been savagely torn, its significance yet unknown.
Singer glanced at his watch. The lecture was fascinating, but he needed another cup of coffee before his meeting with Green. He’d come early out of curiosity and wasn’t disappointed—Green had a commanding presence and a sharp mind.
“So,” Green was saying, “we’re going to use the Oresteia as a window into classical Greek criminology. Orestes represents—”
He faltered.
“Orestes—”
The professor coughed, a small sound at first, then violent. His face flushed crimson before darkening to purple.
Singer jolted to attention.
“Call 911!” he barked at the frozen students, shoving past chairs and tablet arms as he made his way to the front.
Green clawed at his throat, frothy, blood-flecked foam spilling from his mouth. The students, stunned, began to rise.
“Sit down!” Singer bellowed. “This is a police matter. Stay in your seats!”
As he reached the podium, dread settled in his gut. Green slumped forward, lifeless. The professor was beyond saving.
But it wasn’t Green’s collapse that froze Singer in place. It was the object on the podium: another antique book, bound in cognac leather and stamped with a blood-red hand.
Singer’s pulse quickened.
This wasn’t just a puzzle anymore. It was a pattern—and the stakes had just skyrocketed.
description: Academic mystery: a poisoning in a lecture hall

text:
This shouldn’t be possible. Gunnery Sergeant Karim Poole stared at the small figure huddled in the corner. A stowaway. On a warship in deep space.
The girl stared back, lower lip trembling, a dark curl plastered to a tear-streaked cheek. “Have you seen my mommy?” Her voice was a small, frightened whisper. She pressed herself against the junction of the corridor’s glossy white rib and matte wall, ready to bolt.
Damn it. Why me? Poole was terrible with kids. He forced a reassuring tone he didn’t feel. “We’ll find her.” It sounded hollow, even to his own ears. What in God’s name are you doing here?
How had a child breached the ship’s security? Even if she’d slipped past the base’s docking procedures—unlikely, given the stringent protocols—they’d been underway for months. How had she remained hidden for so long?
What has she been eating? The question nagged at him, absurdly insistent.
“What’s your name, sweetie?” The words felt clumsy in his mouth.
“Kel,” she whispered, her voice barely audible.
Oh, hell. Please don’t cry. “That’s a great name,” he said quickly. “My best friend’s name is Kel.” It wasn’t a common name. Maybe this could be a connection. “Why don’t we go find her? She can help us find your mom.”
She sniffled, wiping her nose with the back of her hand.
His Kel—Staff Sergeant Kel Danvers—was good with people. He’d seen her calm down tense situations with a few quiet words. He couldn't imagine her being anything but gentle with a child. He, on the other hand…
The little girl chewed a nail, her gaze fixed on him.
“Come on,” he urged, turning toward the crew quarters. Neither of them was on duty. His wristlet showed Kel in the lounge. He glanced back to ensure the girl was following.
The passageway was empty.
“What the—?” He bit back the curse. There was nowhere for her to go. The corridor curved gently, but a child couldn’t have vanished that quickly. He’d only looked away for a few seconds. Every door required a biometric scan, and hers wouldn’t be in the system.
The hum of the ship, usually a background drone, seemed to amplify, pressing against his eardrums.
The structural ribs lining the corridor weren’t wide enough to hide a child. Still, he checked behind each one, his unease growing.
As he reached a crossway, he heard crying. How…
He turned the corner and stopped dead.
It wasn’t the little girl.
It was Kel.
“Kel?” he whispered, his voice barely a breath.
She stood with her back to him, arms braced against the bulkhead, her body shaking with sobs. Her dark curls were damp, as if she’d just emerged from a shower.
He cleared his throat. “Kel?”
She didn’t react.
He took a hesitant step closer. Kel didn’t break down in public. Something was terribly wrong.
She finally turned, her face flushed and blotchy, eyes red and swollen. “Don’t you dare walk away from me,” she snarled, her voice thick with emotion.
“I’m not,” he stammered. “Kel, what’s wrong? I’m right here.”
She bared her teeth, a raw, animalistic expression on her face. “If you leave now, don’t even think about coming back.”
“What are you talking about?” He felt a chill creep up his spine. “Kel, take a breath. Tell me what’s happening.”
“I mean it.”
He was no longer sure she was seeing him. Her gaze seemed to pierce through him, focusing on something beyond.
He turned.
The passageway behind him was empty.
“What’s…?” He turned back to Kel.
The crossway was empty.
What the absolute fucking hell?
The ship’s hum vibrated through him, a low, unsettling thrum.
He found himself on the deserted storage deck. He’d come for board games, a distraction, but now the idea felt pointless. I need to be around people.
He headed for the lift. And Medical.
Then he heard it: the faint sound of crying.
No. It’s a trick. There’s no girl. And if that was Kel… she needs help.
The crying intensified, a thin, desperate wail.
Damn it. He stopped, his hand hovering over his sidearm. No. Medical. Now. Almost against his will, he turned.
An elderly woman lay on the deck, her breathing shallow, her movements feeble.
This can’t be real.
“Hello?” he called out, his voice strained. “Ma’am, do you need help?”
“Help me,” she gasped, her voice raspy. “Please… someone…”
He took a step closer, drawn by an unseen force. “I’ll get you help. What’s your name?”
She clutched her side, a pained groan escaping her lips. “My name… is Kel Danvers. Please… help me…”
The blood drained from his face. His skin felt clammy, cold. This is impossible.
“Please…” she begged, her eyes pleading.
No. This is insane. He turned and ran, his boots pounding on the metal deck. He didn’t stop until he reached the lift, pacing frantically until the doors opened, then sprinting toward Medical.
He collided with Private First-Class Andre Ortega.
“Christ!” Ortega exclaimed, then flushed crimson. “Sorry, sir!”
“My fault,” Karim managed, his breath ragged.
“Did you hear about what they found? That’s why we changed course. We’re orbiting it now.”
Just get out of my way. “What?” he asked, his voice flat.
“The… I don’t know what it is, sir. I was on the bridge taking lunch orders when they spotted it. On the main viewscreen. We’re not close enough to see it with the naked eye yet.”
“Ortega,” Karim snapped, his patience frayed. “What are you talking about?”
“It’s… gold, sir. Like a honeycomb. Geometric. Huge. Way bigger than the ship.”
“I hadn’t heard.” He mumbled, “Look, Ortega, I’m not feeling well. I need to get to Medical. I’ll hear about it later.”
“Of course, sir. I hope you feel better.” Ortega stepped aside, a nervous smile plastered on his face.
Karim brushed past him, ignoring the curious glances of other crew members.
“What can I do for you, Poole?” the doctor asked. He was younger than Karim preferred, but his brusque manner instilled a sense of confidence.
“I think I’m hallucinating, Doc. Down in storage… I saw people who couldn’t be there.”
“You’re off-duty,” the doctor noted. “Have you been drinking?”
Karim shook his head.
The doctor’s dark eyes narrowed. “Don’t panic, Poole. The stresses of deep space can play tricks on the mind, especially after months out here. You wouldn’t be the first. Rest and some sleep aids should do the trick. We’ll run a full scan, but I suspect that’s all it is.”
“Thanks, Doc.” He let out a shaky breath. “It’s just…”
“Stay off the storage deck for a while,” the doctor said, a faint smile playing on his lips. “It’s creepy down there even under normal circumstances. Stick to the well-lit areas until you’re feeling better. Doctor’s orders.”
“Aye-aye, sir.”
“Good. Let’s get that scan started.” The doctor turned to his console, pressing the call button. “We’ll just—”
A red alert light flashed above the door, and a klaxon blared through the medical bay.
A soft knock at the door.
“Come in,” the doctor called.
A nurse poked his head in. “Doc, we’ve got a critical injury. External maintenance. Staff Sergeant Danvers. Her leg’s caught in a hinge. Comms are down. She’s been out there for a while. Suit’s intact, but she’s unconscious.”
The doctor’s face paled. He moved with sudden urgency. “Surgery pod?”
“Prepped and ready.”
“Let’s go.” He turned back to Karim. “Poole, I’m putting you on medical leave for two weeks. Come back tomorrow for that scan.”
“Yes, sir.” Karim’s voice was barely a whisper. He felt a cold dread settle in his stomach.

text:
Charlotte Eastwick had assumed October would be filled with final wedding preparations and champagne toasts. 
But she wasn’t getting last-minute dress fittings or checking in with wedding musicians. And there were certainly no champagne toasts. 
No, she was walking along the rocky Maine coastline, trying to outpace memories of Devin that chased her like seagulls squaking after scattered bread crumbs.
The breeze off the Atlantic carried the briny scent of seaweed and the faint tang oof dying leaves. Waves crashed against the weathered rocks just off the path, sending up plumes of spray that caught the morning light. In Boston, the leaves would be igniting into their fiery fall glory, but here in Kennebunkport, the coastal winds had already stripped many of the trees bare, leaving their branches to claw at the crystalline blue sky.
Charlie adjusted her grip on her beach umbrella, canvas bag, and the paperback she'd grabbed from the local bookstore that morning. The woman behind the counter had smiled knowingly when Charlie purchased both the romance novel and several bars of chocolate. “You won’t be as lonely as you expect, honey,” she’d promised as she rang up the items. 
Charlie tried to smile in response, but she knew it had come out as more of a grimace. Her perfect fiancé had been running a side business in infidelity. His family had wanted her to go away quietly, and had written her a check with enough zeros to make that happen. 
It was hard to find some sort of bittersweet acceptance when she hadn’t just been jilted, but made to feel like somehow, she was a gold digger for accepting their payoff. It hadn’t been her idea, and she hadn’t been threatening to make a public stink or anything. Devin’s mother had just pressed the check into her hand and said that they should all spare themselves the embarrassment and be dignified about what was happening, then walked away, leaving Charlie staring at the check in numb silence. 
The rocky path opened onto Cleaves Cove Beach, and Charlie’s shoulders eased at the sight of the empty stretch of sand. Perfect. The last thing she wanted was to make awkward small talk with tourists asking why she’d come in the offseason.
She picked her way across the sand, noting how different it felt from the manicured beaches she was used to. This was wild, untamed shoreline, with smooth stones mixed into the sand and tangles of seaweed marking the tide line. She used her foot to smooth a flat stretch of sand and began setting up her umbrella. The wind caught it and nearly yanked it out of her hands, and she muttered some words that would have made Devin’s mother sniff in patrician distaste.
On her third attempt, she finally got the umbrella secured and spread out her towel underneath it. The temperature hovered in the mid-sixties—warm enough in the sun to be comfortable, though when the breeze picked up, it had a bite that spoke of chilly nights. Charlie settled onto her towel and opened her book, determined to lose herself in someone else's romance rather than dwelling on the cratered ruin of her own.
She'd made it through exactly two paragraphs when a shadow fell across the page.
“Hey there.” The voice was deep, friendly, and carried just a hint of a local accent. “Hate to interrupt your reading, but I should probably warn you—this stretch of beach is private property.”
Charlie tilted her head back, squinting against the sun. The man blocking her light was tall, broad-shouldered, and backlit into a silhouette. As her eyes adjusted and he shifted his position, she took in sun-bleached hair, tanned skin, and the kind of strong features that seemed carved by the same natural forces that had shaped the coastline.
“Oh no, I'm so sorry.” Charlie scrambled to her feet, almost taking out her umbrella in the process. “I didn't see any signs.”
“Easy there.” He caught the umbrella before it could become an impromptu projectile. “No harm done. The owners just get pretty territorial about their slice of paradise. They've been known to call the police on unsuspecting tourists.” His smile revealed white teeth just crooked enough not to look artificial and creased the corners of his eyes. “I'm Finn, by the way. Finn Morgan.”
“Charlie—well, Charlotte, but everyone calls me Charlie.” She brushed sand from her legs, suddenly very aware that she was wearing an ancient pair of denim shorts she'd packed purely for comfort and not for aesthetics.
“Tourist or local?” Finn asked. His tone suggested that as a local, he’d have known his own, and was only asking to obey the formalities.
“That obvious, huh?” Charlie managed a self-deprecating smile. “I'm here for a week. Needed a change of scenery.”
“From?”
“Boston.” She hesitated, then added, “Where I was supposed to be getting married next weekend.”
Finn's eyebrows rose. “Supposed to be?”
“Yeah.” Charlie focused on folding her towel, avoiding his gaze. She wanted to add that it turned out that her fiancé believed monogamy was more of a suggestion than a requirement, but she’d deposited that check, and signed the NDA when Devin’s family lawyer followed up. “Not happening, now.”
“Shit.” The word carried genuine sympathy. “That's rough. I'm sorry.”
Charlie shrugged, aiming for casual, even though she hadn’t been all that good at being casual lately. “It is what it is. At least I found out before the wedding, right?”
“Still.” Finn studied her for a moment, then gestured down the beach. “Look, if you're wanting somewhere quiet to read, I know a spot that's actually open to the public. Better view too.”
On one hand, she'd come here specifically to avoid people. If she went with him, she’d be obligated to socialize.
But on the other hand, that idea wasn’t as unappealing as she’d expected. There was something about Finn that put her at ease—maybe it was the way he carried himself, comfortable in his own skin in a way Devin never had been, for all his designer suits and carefully cultivated image.
“You're not going to lead me to some secluded spot and murder me, are you?” She gave him her blandest look.
Finn laughed, the sound carrying over the crash and hiss of the waves. “Nah, murder's not really my thing. Too messy. Besides, I've got lobsters to catch later.” He nodded toward a boat moored further down the coast. “That's my girl there—the Mary Rose.”
“You're a lobsterman?” Charlie fell into step beside him as they walked along the water's edge.
“Born and raised. Family business.” He glanced at her. “What about you? What do you do when you're not escaping wedding drama?”
”Graphic design. Mostly corporate stuff, logos, branding.” She didn't mention that she'd been about to launch her own firm, before everything imploded and Devin's family's hush money offered her a respite from working so she could take some time to nurse her broken heart. The NDA she'd signed felt like it was burning through her back pocket, even though the actual document was locked in her desk drawer back home.
They rounded a bend in the coastline, and Charlie breathed out an impressed sigh. A small cove opened up before them, protected by rocky outcrops on either side. The water here was a deeper blue, and there were some large, flat rocks that looked like someone might have dragged them out here to provide seating.
“This is gorgeous,” she said, meaning it.
“Local secret.” Finn grinned. “Well, semi-secret. The tourists usually stick to the main beaches.” He glanced up at the sky, which was still a brilliant, unadulterated blue. “Just keep an eye on the weather. Storms come up fast around here, especially this time of year. Tide can come in real fast when the wind shifts.”
Charlie nodded, already imagining how perfect this spot would be for reading. Or thinking. Or just existing without the weight of everything crushing her.
“I should get back to the boat,” Finn said. “But I'm sure I'll see you around. Small town and all that.”
“Thanks for the rescue.” Charlie smiled, surprised to find it didn't feel forced. “And the local intel.”
“Any time.” He turned to go, then paused. “Oh, and Charlie? Your ex is an idiot.”
Before she could respond, he was walking away, his long strides eating up the sand. Charlie watched him go, feeling something warm unclench in her chest—something that felt dangerously like hope.
With a shake of her head, she set up her umbrella again and settled in with her book. But her mind kept wandering from the pages to the way Finn's eyes had crinkled when he smiled, and how his voice had wrapped around her nickname like he'd been saying it for years.
She told herself firmly to stop it. She was here to heal, not to court more potential heartbreak. But as the waves crashed against the rocks and the October sun warmed her skin, Charlie found herself hoping she'd run into Finn Morgan again—preferably before the storms rolled in.
description: Beachy romance: Charlotte finds unexpected hope in Kennebunkport

text:
Sarah Chen’s fingertips waited over the keys as Congressman James Barrett’s voice filled the room. The great hope of his party paced the office like a caged tiger, the sharp clap of his shoes against the polished hardwood punctuating his words. The fluorescent lights overhead cast a harsh glow on the walls adorned with framed photos of him shaking hands with farmers, veterans, and children—the quintessential man of the people.
“The American people,” Barrett declared, his syllables precise and rhythmic, “deserve to know how their tax dollars are being spent. Not tomorrow, not next year, but today.” He paused, his Paul Newman blue eyes locking onto Sarah. “Too strong?”
Sarah glanced down at the text of the speech on her laptop, the cursor blinking in sync with her quickening pulse. “I think it’s just right,” she offered, her voice carefully measured. “It’s… commanding.”
Barrett nodded thoughtfully and resumed pacing, the script in his hand rustling, dry and sharp against the hum of the radiator. He had a way of moving that demanded attention, every gesture deliberate, every change of posture calculated.
“Commanding,” he echoed, testing the word. “But not too aggressive?”
“Not at all,” Sarah confirmed, though she wasn’t entirely sure. He always sought her input, dissecting the cadence and rhythm of each line, but his questions left her feeling like she was being tested. She supposed it was flattering—as a freshman aide, she never would have expected her opinion to matter to a man on the eve of a presidential campaign. But for some reason it felt… off. 
“Let’s tweak the second half,” Barrett murmured, flipping through the pages. “What if we reframe it? Something like, ‘They have a right to demand transparency, because it’s their money.’ More personal. More immediate.”
“Making the change,” Sarah promised as she typed. The new line appeared on her screen, and she read it back to him.
Barrett closed his eyes, mouthing the words, like he was tasting them. Then he opened his eyes again, his gaze sharpening. “That’ll do. Let’s move on.”
Sarah adjusted her glasses and scrolled down. Her job was simple: transcribe his words and be a sounding board. And yet, every time they worked through a speech, she felt that nagging unease skitter up her spine. Barrett’s public persona was magnetic, his rhetoric powerful, his conviction palpable. But behind closed doors, he seemed like a different person. Not insincere, exactly, but detached, as though the fiery speeches were just lines he was delivering in a play.
Barrett stopped suddenly, mid-pace. “Sarah, what about the word ‘demand’? Too harsh? Would ‘expect’ work better, or does that weaken it?”
She hesitated, not sure she really knew. “I think ‘demand’ has more weight. It’s stronger. ‘Expect’ feels a bit… passive.”
The congressman nodded, running a hand through his perfectly styled hair. “Good point. Demand it is.” He resumed pacing, but this time his voice was softer, almost reflective. “You know, sometimes I wonder how much people really care about this stuff. I wonder if they’re really processing what I’m saying, or just clapping along when my delivery tells them it’s an applause line. Do you think they’re even paying attention?”
She would have been less startled if he’d broken into song and dance. “I think… I think they care when someone like you makes them care. You have a way of connecting with people.” She hoped that was the right answer.
Barrett smiled, but it didn’t quite touch his eyes. “That’s kind of you to say.” He resumed his pacing, murmuring lines under his breath. 
Her phone buzzed, and she jumped, fumbling to silence it. Barrett stopped mid-sentence, turning back to her with an arched brow.
“Sorry,” she stammered. “I should’ve muted it.”
To her surprise, he smiled again. “Don’t worry about it. I needed a break anyway.” He set the script down and stretched, rolling his shoulders. “I’m going to grab some coffee. Take fifteen minutes. You’ve earned it.”
“Thanks.” She needed a break. She wasn’t sure why these sessions unnerved her so much. The congressman disappeared through the door, leaving her alone in the quiet of the office. She picked up her phone and glanced at the screen. 
There was a text from an unknown number. A blocked number. 
She opened it, expecting some sort of spam.
Your boss isn’t who you think he is. If you want the truth, look for a bush near the Senate Fountain with a plastic bag caught on it. Look under it.
For a moment, Sarah’s mind went blank. Was it a prank? Some kind of joke? She glanced at the door, half expecting Barrett to walk back in, smirking at her gullibility. 
But if she reported it, they would trace it. Hunt down whoever had sent it. There was a whole political apparatus behind Barrett, invested in making sure that nothing tarnished the presidential chances of the party’s golden boy. 
And on the off-chance that there was something to this accusation, she’d certainly never know. 
Before she could second-guess herself, she deleted the message, closed her laptop, and grabbed her coat.
The air outside was crisp, carrying the scent of exhaust and the murmur of distant traffic. The Senate Fountain loomed ahead, its water sparkling in the fading dusk light. Sarah’s heels clicked against the pavement as she approached it.
For a moment, she was almost relieved that it had been a hoax.
And then she saw it. A crumpled plastic bag, caught on the lower branches of a manicured bush. Her heart thudded as she walked over to it, glancing around to make sure no one was watching, and crouched, feeling around the bush’s trunk. The area seemed deserted, but her skin prickled with the sensation of being observed.
Her fingers brushed against something smooth in the mulch. She pulled it free: a Ziploc bag, sealed tightly, with a thumb drive inside. Her breath caught as she turned it over in her hands. No markings, no note, just the drive.
She stayed crouched there for a long moment. This was insane. She was an aide to one of the most prominent congressmen in the country, not some spy in an airport bookstore political thriller. But the weight of the drive in her hand felt undeniable, like a stone dropped into a still pond, sending ripples through her carefully ordered world.
She slipped it into her pocket and stood, brushing off her coat. 
Then, numb, she began walking slowly back to the Dirksen Building. 
When she reached Barrett’s office, he was already back, coffee in hand, his expression as calm and collected as ever. “Ready to pick up where we left off?” he asked. His tone was warm, easy.
Sarah nodded, forcing a smile. 
The drive in her pocket felt hot, like it was burning a whole through the fabric and scorching her skin, even though she knew if she pressed her fingers to it, it would be cool to the touch. 
She sat down and opened her laptop.
description: Political thriller: Sarah discovers a mysterious thumb drive

text:
The wind whipped across the exposed mountainside, carrying on its sharp and insistent edge the scent of damp earth and distant pine. Dr. Elias Vinter hunched deeper into his worn Barbour jacket, tugging the collar higher around his ears. He glanced up at the bruised grey sky, a familiar knot of anxiety tightening in his stomach. The weather had been threatening for days, slate-dark clouds hovering over the northern Norwegian momtains. The locals kept warning about sudden, violent storms.
Elias straightened his spine, pushing his worries aside. This dig, this remote Viking ship burial nestled high in the unforgiving landscape, was his focus. It had to be. 
Academia could be brutal at the best of times, and a dry spell of publications that stretched into years was no way to get tenure. He knew his lectures were rote, a dreary repetition of well-worn material. 
And then there was his marriage.
This discovery, this excavation, was a chance to feel alive again, to be inspired to publish, to wreak some sort of hope from the wreckage of his career. 
The site was its usual hive of activity. A team of students, their faces flushed with exertion and the chill air, carefully brushed away layers of earth, revealing more of the long, elegant lines of the buried ship. Weathered local workers moved deftly amongst them. The rhythmic clang of trowels against stone, the low murmur of conversations in both Norwegian and English, and the ever-present sigh of the wind created a constant, almost hypnotic hum.
Elias’s current task was meticulously documenting the area surrounding the ship's stern. He knelt on a small, portable stool, his fingers numb with cold. He refused to wear gloves. He wanted to feel his future in the dust and ancient wood. 
The fine, grey soil clung to everything, coating his hands, his clothes, even the lenses of his glasses. He squinted through the fogged lenses, carefully brushing away another layer of dirt from a section of what appeared to be a collapsed timber. The air was thick with the earthy smell of damp soil and the fainter, metallic tang of ancient iron.
It took a while before he noticed the rumbling echoing through the valley. He swore under his breath and looked up, eyeing he darkening clouds caught on the mountain peaks. A flicker of lightning cast the scene in eerie relief for a second, and the answering low growl of thunder was louder this time. The wind was picking up, tugging at the tarpaulins that partially covered the dig site.
“Looks like we’re in for it,” a voice boomed beside him. It was Bjørn, one of the local workers, a man built like a fortress with a loud laugh and eyes looked like they’d seen things best forgotten, here in these hills. “The old gods are restless today.”
Elias nodded, humoring him. He suspected the locals liked to unnerve the students with hints at dark tales from more brutal times, a gesture in the direction of the otherworldly. He, on the other hand, had had all his credulity ground away by long years of compromise and disappointment. He glanced at the other workers, who were beginning to move with a tight urgency, securing the tarpaulins and gathering their tools.
Apparently the weather wasn’t going to let them continue to work. As he gathered his tools, a faint green glint in the dust caught his eye. There was a shape visible in the fine dust near where he had been working. He dropped most of his tools into his bag, keeping a soft brush out, and brushed away the fine gray dust covering the object. At first he thought it might be a shard of green glass, but it appeared to be embedded in something larger. 
He almost didn’t notice the first fat drops of rain that began to splash into the dust. The wind howled, and a clap of thunder, closer than the last few, shook the dust. 
“Elias! We need to go!” Dr. Astrid Olsen, his colleague and the lead archaeologist on the dig, dropped a hand on his shoulder. Her voice was sharp. “The locals are saying this could turn really nasty. We’ve got the site as secured as we can get it. We need to get down to the village.”
Elias scowled at the scene. The sky was getting almost as dark as if the sun had set, and the rain was beginning to sheet down, rattling the tarps. The other workers were scrambling into the waiting Jeeps parked at the edge of the site. 
“Just a minute,” Elias told Astrid, shouting over the wind and rain. “I think I found something.” He gestured at the mud in front of him. The rain had washed away more of the dirt, exposing more of the object. 
“Who cares?” Astrid shouted back. “We need to get out of here. They’re saying there are likely to be mudslides. It’s not safe!”
He knew she was right. There were rapidly swelling streams snaking down the mountainside and the tail lights of the Jeeps carrying the students and workers away were already disappearing around the curve in the road. There were two Jeeps remaining, and two local workers were climbing into one of them, shouting and gesturing at him and Astrid. But something held him rooted to the spot. 
“I’ll just mark this find,” he said, his voice strained. “I’ll be right behind you. Ride down with them, leave me the last Jeep. I’ll follow in a few minutes.”
Astrid hesitated, her expression torn between concern and exasperation. Finally, with a sigh, she handed him her set of keys and turned and hurried towards the waiting vehicles. “Your funeral!” she yelled back over her shoulder.
Elias watched them go. The rain was coming down in torrents now, soaking him to the skin. He barely noticed. His entire attention was focused on the figurine.
As the rain continued to wash away the soil, the figure became clearer. It was crudely carved of some dark, almost black material. He couldn’t tell if it was stone or metal. It appeared to be a figure of a woman, though the details were worn and indistinct. The glint of green he had seen earlier was now revealed to be two small, cloudy green gems embedded in the figure’s head, giving it an eerie, blind stare.
He began to carefully work it free from the earth, his fingers tracing the rough contours of its form. He found himself thinking of it as “her,” a strange, almost possessive thought.
As he gently loosened the figurine from the clinging soil, he discovered that she was mounted on the back of a small, muscular-looking warhorse. The details were crude, but there was an odd power to the lines of the sculpture. 
The wind howled, and a sudden, ominous clattering sound made him jump. He looked up to see a nearby pile of stones beginning to slide down the mountainside, dislodged by the relentless rain. The ground beneath him was becoming saturated, the small streams around the dig site turning into rushing torrents.
He looked back down at the figurine, his jaw suddenly aching. He realized he had been holding a broad, almost manic grin for some time, without even realizing it. He wasn’t sure how long he had been sitting there, in the pouring rain, grinning at nothing.
With a jolt, he snapped out of his trance. The rain was as hard to see through as fog, and the wind threatened to tear the remaining tarpaulins from their moorings. He had to get out of there.
Carefully, almost reverently, he wrapped the figurine in the sopping towel that he had been using to clean his tools. He shoved it into his jacket pocket, the cold, wet object pressing against his chest.
He scrambled to his feet, his muscles stiff and aching, and squelched through the mud towards his Jeep, the wind and rain buffeting him from all sides. 
As he fumbled with the keys, he knew one thing with absolute certainty. 
He wasn’t going to tell anyone about this find. This was his, and his alone.
description: Archaeological horror: Elias becomes obsessed with a strange find

text:
These mountains had a way of making Elias Vinter feel small. Not the way his department head did last week, with that thin-lipped look that meant publish or perish, but something older. The wind cut through his Barbour jacket - the one Ingrid had given him years ago, saying he looked like a proper archaeologist now. The memory stung worse than the cold.
Dark clouds massed above the peaks. He'd learned to read weather at dozens of dig sites across three continents, but these Norwegian storms were different. The locals knew it. He caught their glances, the way they watched the sky like they were expecting something. Their warnings about the mountains' moods had seemed quaint three weeks ago. Now, not so much.
The Viking ship emerged from the earth like a secret telling itself. His students worked with more enthusiasm than skill, and sometimes he had to look away, remembering his own early disasters. That site in Peru, when he'd nearly destroyed a pristine textile layer. His old mentor would have known exactly what to say about their technique. But his old mentor wasn't speaking to him these days, not since the Uppsala controversy.
His knees cracked as he shifted on his camp stool, documenting the stern section. The soil here had its own personality, clingy and grey, turning everything it touched into a ghost of itself. Something about the texture reminded him of the chalk dust that had covered his hands after lectures. Back when he still cared enough to gesture.
The first tremor caught him mid-thought. Thunder rolled through the valley like a giant's hunger. Lightning sketched the ship's outline in brutal clarity, and for a moment he could see it as it must have been - proud and terrible, bearing its dead to eternal rest. The tarps snapped overhead like sails in a storm he'd rather forget.
Bjørn appeared like a mountain taking human form. ”The old ones are walking.” His voice carried the weight of generations who'd learned to fear these peaks. Elias started to nod, but something in the soil caught his eye.
Green. Just a flash, like broken bottle glass, except...
Rain began falling, fat drops that meant business. More thunder, closer now. He kept digging. His fingers remembered other artifacts, other discoveries that had meant everything until they didn't. His last paper rejection sat unopened in his email. Ingrid's lawyer was still waiting for a response. None of it mattered. The green thing in the dirt pulled at him like an unfinished sentence.
”Elias!” Astrid's voice cut through the wind. She never showed fear - it was one of the things he'd first noticed about her as a project lead. But fear threaded through his name now. ”The locals are calling it! We need to clear out!”
He looked up. When had it gotten so dark? The crew ran for their vehicles, abandoning tools like a sinking ship. Rain painted everything in sheets of grey.
”Just give me a minute.” His voice sounded strange in his ears. ”There's something here.”
”The whole slope could go!” The terror in Astrid's voice should have meant something to him. Should have.
”I'll follow in my Jeep.” A lie told itself through his mouth.
He watched their taillights bleed into the rain. The mountain shuddered. The thing in the ground waited.
The figure emerged from the earth like a birth gone wrong. Dark material, not quite stone, not quite bone. A woman astride a war-horse, crude but powerful. The green stones set in her face weren't eyes - they were hunger made visible. They stared at nothing, at everything. At him.
His hands moved without permission. The figure came free. Recognition hit him like vertigo - not of the thing itself, but of what it meant to want something so badly you'd let the mountain fall around you.
He wrapped it in his cleaning cloth, the one still stained with coffee from countless mornings of shaking hands and delayed decisions. Pressed it to his chest like a confession.
The rain tried to blind him as he fought his way to his Jeep. The dig site dissolved behind him. Years of careful work turned to mud and memory.
The figure rode against his heart, a secret turning into truth. The mountain's judgment followed him down into darkness.
description: Archaeological horror: a Norwegian dig yields troubling secrets

Delete it delete it del—

doesn't matter
Night wind carries exhaust and secrets. Fountain water catches light like scattered coins. Her heels click too loud on concrete—everything too loud, too exposed. But the area stands empty. For now.
Pantyhose snags and dies on the bush. Plastic gleams like a dead thing. Her hands shake as they find something smooth, hard. The drive sits black and hungry in her palm. No marks. No clues. Just questions wrapped in plastic.
She stands there too long. This isn't some political thriller. This is her life, her career, her future balanced on the edge of a thumb drive.
Back in the lemon-sharp office. Barrett's coffee steam writes warnings she can't quite read. ”Ready to continue?” Voice smooth as antifreeze.

How many others got texts?

text:
The thing about October in Maine is it smells like endings. Charlotte Eastwick stood at the edge of the water, breathing in salt and dead seaweed and that weird smoky smell that shows up right before winter, and tried not to think about how she should've been back in Boston right now, arguing with the florist about last-minute substitutions for the peonies that hadn't bloomed in time.
The wind kept trying to steal her umbrella. Beach umbrella in October - jesus, what was she even doing here? But the alternative was sitting in her rented cottage reading through the NDA one more time, like maybe this time she'd find a loophole, something that would let her tell the whole world exactly what kind of man Devin Morrison turned out to be. His parents' check had a lot of zeros, though. Enough zeros to shut up about their precious son and his extracurricular dating habits.
The trees up here were already mostly bare, which felt appropriate. Back home they'd be showing off, all gold and red and look-how-pretty-dying-can-be. Here they just gave up and got it over with, branches clawing at a sky so blue it hurt to look at. Charlie adjusted her death grip on her beach gear - umbrella, bag, that stupid romance novel she'd bought that morning. The bookstore clerk had looked at her purchase (novel, chocolate bar, more chocolate) like she was one sad indie movie away from adopting seventeen cats.
”Bad breakup?” the woman had asked, in that particular New England way that somehow made it both a question and a statement.
Charlie had managed something between a smile and a grimace. How exactly do you explain that your fiancé's ”networking events” turned out to be more horizontal than vertical? That his mother had shown up at your apartment with a checkbook and a contract, talking about ”discretion” and ”family reputation” like she was casting The Godfather?
The rocky path dumped her out onto Cleaves Cove Beach, which stretched empty in both directions. Thank christ. She really couldn't handle one more conversation with helpful tourists asking why she was vacationing alone, their faces doing that awkward dance between sympathy and judgment when she mentioned the canceled wedding.
This wasn't one of those neat, managed beaches with imported sand and carefully spaced chairs. Nature had dumped whatever it felt like here - smooth stones, chunks of driftwood, tangles of seaweed that looked like mermaid hair gone wrong. It took Charlie three attempts and more swearing than strictly necessary to get the umbrella planted in a way that wouldn't send it cartwheeling down the beach.
The temperature was playing that fun fall game where it's simultaneously too hot and too cold. Charlie spread out her towel in the umbrella's shade, pulled out her book (shiny cover, bare-chested man, absolutely zero infidelity plot twists guaranteed), and managed exactly two paragraphs before a shadow fell across the page.
”So here's the thing.” The voice above her was pure Down East, warm and rich as good coffee. ”You're technically trespassing.”
Charlie tilted her head back and immediately regretted it as the sun blinded her. When her vision cleared, she found herself looking at the kind of man L.L.Bean probably had locked in a basement somewhere for catalog photo shoots. Tall, broad-shouldered, with that sun-bleached hair and weathered skin that said he actually worked outside instead of just playing at it on weekends.
”Oh god, I'm sorry.” She scrambled up, nearly decapitating herself with the umbrella in the process. ”I didn't see any signs.”
”Whoa, easy.” He caught the umbrella before it could complete its mission of death. ”No big deal. Just wanted to warn you before Mrs. Henderson calls the cops again. She's got nothing better to do than police her precious beach frontage.” His smile made it all the way to his eyes, creating the kind of crinkles Devin probably had Botoxed away. ”I'm Finn. Finn Morgan.”
”Charlie. Well, Charlotte, but nobody calls me that except my grandmother and people trying to sell me things.” She brushed sand from her legs, suddenly very aware that she was wearing the kind of shorts that should have been retired during the Obama administration.
”Let me guess. Boston?”
”That obvious?”
”Little bit.” The way he said it made it feel like a shared joke instead of an accusation. ”What brings you up the coast?”
”Canceled wedding.” The words just fell out of her mouth like stones. ”Next weekend, actually.”
His eyebrows did a thing. ”Damn. That's rough.”
Charlie focused very hard on folding her towel. ”Yeah, well. Turns out monogamy was more of a suggestion than a requirement for him.”
”Christ.” He managed to pack a whole paragraph of sympathy into one word. ”Look, there's a public beach just around that bend. Better spot anyway. The view's something else.”
She should say no. She came here specifically to avoid people, not to follow gorgeous strangers to secondary locations. But there was something about him that felt... safe. Real. The opposite of Devin's careful polish and practiced charm.
”You're not going to murder me and dump my body in the Atlantic, right?”
His laugh bounced off the water. ”Nah, got a boat full of traps waiting. That's my girl down there - Mary Rose.”
Somehow they were walking, falling into step like they'd done it before. He asked what she did (”Graphic design, mostly boring corporate stuff”), and she asked about lobstering (”Family business, since my grandfather decided farming was too easy”). She didn't mention the design firm she'd been about to launch, or the way Devin's mother had smiled when Charlie signed away her right to tell anyone why the wedding was really canceled.
The beach he led her to was straight out of some travel magazine's ”Hidden Gems of New England” spread. A perfect little cove, sheltered by rocky arms, with water so blue it looked painted. Someone had even arranged the rocks into natural benches.
”Local secret,” Finn said, looking pleased at her obvious appreciation. ”Just keep an eye on the weather. Storms come up fast this time of year. Like, really fast.”
He had to get back to his boat, but he turned back before he left. ”Hey Charlie? Your ex is what my mother would call a complete goddamn waste of oxygen.”
She watched him walk away, all easy grace and broad shoulders, and felt something crack open in her chest. Something that felt like maybe the universe wasn't completely done with her yet.
*Stop it*, she ordered herself. She was here to put herself back together, not to fall for the first beautiful stranger who smiled at her like she mattered. But as she settled back with her book, she caught herself hoping she'd run into Finn Morgan again. Preferably before those storms he'd mentioned rolled in and washed away all traces of this strange, perfect morning.
description: Beachy romance: fleeing heartbreak to the Maine coast

text:
I awoke to unfamiliar luxury: clean sheets, smelling of flowers that dot the countryside here, which children call “Lady’s Veil.” The flowers’ wistful scent was said to ease troubled sleep.
There was an old folksong about a young man who met a maiden in a field and, overcome by her grace, clasped her close and attempted to pull back her veil. She changed shape six times, each form more deadly than the last. In her seventh form, the edge of her veil sliced him open like a blade. She fled into the forest, and he followed, his blood mingling with the flowers that bloomed beneath her feet, leaving the center of each pale blue blossom stained crimson. I’d heard young girls tell it as a tragic love story, and old men cite it as a parable about the glory and danger inherent in loving the divine. 
Personally, I thought it was a good warning for people who can’t keep their hands to themselves. 
A vague memory of seeing the school in the distance late last night, bone-weary after a week’s ride from the site of our last job and the incessant squabbling of my companions, teased me. I thought I remembered the school’s healer shooing me into bed. 
I was home, or the closest thing I had to it.
The sunlight was slanting in through the leaded diamond panes of my window, but I was still languorous with the remnants of well-earned sleep. I had just slithered onto my stomach and pulled the sheet over my head when the breakfast bell began ringing.
Bother.
Resentful, I climbed out of bed. I pulled on a pair of soft leather breeches, a white linen shirt, and my boots, then a vest that concealed a few daggers and my thieves’ tools. Sliding another dagger into each boot, I headed downstairs for breakfast.  
The hallways were largely devoid of the normal morning bustle. I did see a bleary-looking Pepwinn dragged from his room by his starved-looking wolf, but I skipped down the stone stairway before he could greet me.
At the bottom of the stairs, I stuck my head into the storeroom that led into the kitchen. A harried-looking cook paused in sorting through a barrel of dried fruit to look inquiringly at me. “One more for breakfast,” I told her.
She nodded, a chestnut curl falling into her eyes. “Extra ham for you, healer says, Miss Elspeth,” she said briskly. “Don’t be looking sour at me, young miss.” I tried to put my face back into a pleasant expression. “Healer says you’re almost all used up, and need to be building back your strength. Tain’t worth it to argue with a healer, lass  good ones are right bullies, they are.” She couldn’t have been much older than me, but I dropped my chin meekly and agreed. “Into the hall with you, now, and I’ll have your meal out to you in a trice, and you’ll clean your plate, and neither of us will have to answer to Her Healerness.”
I turned to go, then looked back over my shoulder. “Liss, who made up my bed? Someone scented the sheets with lady’s veil flowers, and I wanted to thank whichever housekeeper was so thoughtful.”
Her blue eyes widened, and she beamed. “That were Jenta, the head housekeeper’s daughter. You been in her gaze e’er since you showed her how to pick the pantry lock  ’n yes, we know it were you, so don’t bother denying. The little maid heard the other students saying as how you should be home soon, and how you’d cleared the risen dead out of that tomb and saved the town. She were worried you’d not sleep easy after bumping noses with ghosts and ghouls and rats and the like, so while the other children were playing she slipped off and gathered the veilflowers. Then she nipped at Meyla’s heels until she washed the sheets with the petals. The little one’s a right angel, I say, and I wish me younger sisters were half as sweet.”
“Please pass my thanks to Meyla,” I said. “I’ll find Jenta and thank her myself, and try to avoid corrupting her with any more lockpicking lessons.”
“See as you do,” the cook huffed, grinning. “Now away with you. I’ve your breakfast to get.”
I opened the door to the Great Hall and was met with a wall of sound woven of the voices of the other nineteen students in residence at the school (eighteen more maintained rooms at nearby inns) and the clanking of dishes and utensils.
“Elspeth!” called Luthar, the closest thing I had to a friend, from one of the long, scarred tables. “Here, I saved a place for you.” I slid onto the bench next to him, and he poured me a glass of cider from the pitcher shared by our half of the table. 
The table quieted and my classmates leaned in. “Well?” Luthar demanded. 
“It wasn’t glorious,” I told my audience. “Most of it was wet, cold and unpleasant.”
They looked disappointed, so, seizing this rare moment of rapport with my classmates, I gave in and regaled them with a slightly embellished version of the cleansing of the tomb. Looking around at their shining eyes, I started to feel a bit strange about just how impressed they were. All I’d really done, after all, was exactly what we’d all been trained to do. The hero-worship from the people of the village had been more or less expected, but seeing the same from my peers was unnerving. The whole reason we were all here was to learn real survival and exploring skills, the stark realities unvarnished by all the nonsense bards sing about. 
The Academy wasn’t the sort of fighting school that young people outside of our little country dream of attending. Announcing you’d been a student there wasn’t likely to score you free drinks from callow would-be adventurers in taverns across the region. It wouldn’t draw lovers intent on bedding a hero. You wouldn’t be able to trade on school ties to step into an otherwise unearned command post with an army or mercenary troop. 
Arturus’s academy boasted one feature that the sort of school that offered those benefits usually couldn’t, however: a large contingent of retiredthat is, still-livingalumni throughout the region.
“So, anyone have any interesting plans for after graduation?” I asked, wanting my classmates to go back to looking at me like I was one of them. 
Luthar traced the grain of the table, scarred with use and names and slogans from generations of hungry students, with a broad finger. He was from Alvar, the biggest metropolis in the region, and his parents had sent him to the Academy to learn the skills needed to follow in their footsteps as explorers and treasure-hunters. He was, I imagine, a perfect presumptive candidate: polished, urbane, and irrepressible. 
He was also in giddy, stultifying love with a pretty young woman from the local village of Stardale, and in serious discussions with her family about marriage and eventually taking over their farm. He was clearly thinking about her now, because he wore a slightly poleaxed smile.
Cari, a tiny woman with a curly mop of hair, smiled with a bright flash of teeth. “Going back to my troop. They’ll have to take me seriously now that I’ve been here.” She was a member of a successful mercenary group and was looking forward to a commission. 
The others at the table were locals, planning to join the militia which was the closest thing the country had to a government. 
“And you?” Cari asked me. “What does the future hold for the mysterious Elspeth?”
I felt my eyebrows make a grab for my hairline. “Mysterious” was one of the last words I’d choose to describe myself. “I was planning to head to Alvar and try to find a merc troop that’ll take me.”
“If you’re done with our heroine,” a new voice broke in from immediately behind me, “I need her elsewhere.”
I jumped several inches off the bench and twisted my neck over my shoulder. Professor Nura El-Ameen, priestess of the sun goddess and our tutor in protection spells and dealing with outsiders, beckoned graciously to me, as if it were merely a request. “Bring your breakfast, Elspeth. You’re looking a bit wan,” she added. 
Professor El-Ameen came from a far-off desert empire. In contrast to the stereotypes about desert princesses, the professor dressed plainly. A closer look at her robes, however, told an observer that this was no novice priestess; while simple, they were of fine silk, pale blue with a subtle but ornate gold sunburst pattern that only revealed itself when the light hit it at certain angles. 
I offered the occasional prayer and coin to the goddess of fortune because it made sense to have a good relationship with the lady of luck, but I wasn’t particularly religious. The professor, however, whatever ecstatic rites she might be rumored to practice in private, projected such an air of quiet common sense in public that it was only natural to go to her for advice, and she never tried to convert us.
“Am I in trouble?” I asked her as she guided me from the great hall. 
“Quite the opposite,” said the professor. “A young woman from the village is here and wishes to convey her town’s gratitude to you, both verbally and, I think, in a more tangible form. She’s waiting in the parlor. How are you feeling, by the way? Any lingering aches or abrasions from your experience?” 
“Dan took most of the damage,” I demurred, although I couldn’t help flexing my elbow and wincing. 
The professor’s dark eyes narrowed at the movement, and she stopped me as we walked through a shaft of sunlight into the hallway. She stared out at the sun, the strong lines of her profile softening and her eyes turning amber as she murmured a quick invocation to her goddess. 
The sunlight wrapped around me as if it had weight and substance. The heat of it should have been uncomfortable, but it felt friendly instead. It melted through my skin, purring along my bones and brushing away the last of the tomb’s chill. The pain in my elbow faded, and a sense of perfect well-being enfolded me. 
I opened my eyes, though I didn’t remember closing them. Motes of dust danced in the light, forming a sparkling veil over the priestess. She was smiling up at the sun. The dust motes swirled around her merrily, gleaming like miniature suns, as if the goddess were also enjoying the exchange. 
“No more, please,” I said dryly, “or you might tempt me into apostasy, and anyone in my line of work shouldn’t get on the lady of fortune’s bad side.” My voice came out hoarsely, as if I’d just awakened from a deep sleep. “You worship a dangerous goddess, professor.”   
Professor El-Ameen’s eyes cooled into their normal dark brown as she turned them to me, and something crossed her face, though whether it was quick-hidden laughter or pain, I couldn’t say. 
“All gods are dangerous.”
